Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS).title: The Story of Enhancing Recovery after Surgery.
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS).author: N/A
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS).abstract_summary: This review discusses the multimodal approach of Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) to control postoperative pathophysiology and improve rehabilitation. It highlights that by addressing the surgical stress response through various interventions, ERAS aims to reduce complications, shorten recovery time, and decrease overall healthcare costs.

Preoperative Iron Deficiency.title: Non-anaemic iron deficiency in surgical patients: more than just a laboratory finding?
Preoperative Iron Deficiency.author: N/A
Preoperative Iron Deficiency.abstract_summary: This article discusses the high prevalence of non-anaemic iron deficiency in surgical patients. It highlights the conflicting and scant evidence regarding its impact on postoperative outcomes. The authors call for further investigation with clear definitions to determine the clinical significance of this condition.

Preoperative Iron Deficiency.title: Association of non-anaemic iron deficiency with postoperative outcomes after fast-track hip and knee arthroplasty: a prospective cohort study.
Preoperative Iron Deficiency.author: N/A
Preoperative Iron Deficiency.abstract_summary: This prospective cohort study of 4883 patients investigated the impact of preoperative non-anaemic iron deficiency on outcomes after fast-track hip and knee arthroplasty. Although a statistically significant association with days alive and at home was found, the clinical importance was minimal. The study concludes that correcting preoperative iron deficiency without anaemia is unlikely to improve common postoperative outcomes in these procedures.

Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Preoperativ.title: Characteristics and outcome of preoperative multidisciplinary team discussions for high-risk noncardiac surgical patients in the Netherlands: a multicentre prospective observational study.
Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Preoperativ.author: N/A
Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) Preoperativ.abstract_summary: This prospective study observed 225 high-risk noncardiac surgical patients discussed in preoperative multidisciplinary team (MDT) meetings across nine Dutch hospitals. MDT discussions led to management modifications in 81% of patients, with nearly one-third avoiding surgery altogether. The findings highlight the significant impact of MDT on clinical decision-making and the high rate of adverse events in this population, underscoring the need for further research on its effectiveness.

Sarcopenia and Myosteatosis as Risk Fact.title: Association Between Two Muscle-Related Parameters and Postoperative Complications in Patients Undergoing Colorectal Tumor Resection Surgery.
Sarcopenia and Myosteatosis as Risk Fact.author: N/A
Sarcopenia and Myosteatosis as Risk Fact.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of 317 patients investigated the link between preoperative muscle mass (L3 SMI) and muscle density (HUAC) with complications after colorectal tumor surgery. The study found that myosteatosis (low muscle density) was significantly associated with a higher risk of postoperative complications, especially severe ones. The authors suggest that screening for myosteatosis using preoperative CT scans could help identify high-risk patients.

Preoperative Risk Assessment Models.title: Development and validation of a predictive model for transfusion in major abdominal surgery: a multicentre retrospective study.
Preoperative Risk Assessment Models.author: N/A
Preoperative Risk Assessment Models.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a nomogram to predict the need for intraoperative red blood cell transfusion in major abdominal surgery, using data from over 200,000 patients. The model, incorporating seven preoperative variables like age, ASA status, and hemoglobin, demonstrated good predictive ability and calibration across different hospital datasets. This tool can help optimize blood utilization and improve patient management by identifying high-risk individuals.

Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.title: Enhancing Anesthetic Preoptimization: Promising Opportunities for Innovation in Economically Diverse Regions.
Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.author: N/A
Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.abstract_summary: This review highlights the critical role of anesthesiologists in preoperative patient optimization to improve quality and cost-effectiveness of care, especially in resource-limited areas. It discusses key conditions like sleep apnea, hypertension, anemia, and diabetes that can be managed preoperatively to reduce surgical morbidity and mortality. The paper emphasizes the need for a systems-based approach and identifies existing gaps in preoperative management.

Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.title: Understanding preoperative concerns and attitudes towards prehabilitation in older surgical populations: A survey study.
Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.author: N/A
Preoperative Optimization and Patient Co.abstract_summary: This multicenter survey of 236 older surgical patients identified common preoperative concerns, with postoperative pain and surgical complications being the most significant. While attitudes towards prehabilitation and functional assessments were positive, willingness to undergo preoperative memory testing was low. The findings suggest a need to tailor prehabilitation programs to address specific patient concerns and improve accessibility and adherence in older adults.

Preoperative Cognitive Screening.title: The utility of the Ascertain Dementia Eight-item Questionnaire (AD8) and Mini-Cog in detecting cognitive impairment in older surgical patients - The Detect CI study.
Preoperative Cognitive Screening.author: N/A
Preoperative Cognitive Screening.abstract_summary: This study evaluated two ultra-rapid cognitive screening tools, AD8 and Mini-Cog, in 394 older surgical patients against the validated MoCA tool. Both tools showed moderate accuracy, but the AD8 was better associated with poorer preoperative patient-centered assessments and higher 90-day adverse outcomes. The study highlights the importance of preoperative cognitive screening and suggests the AD8 is a valuable tool for identifying at-risk patients.

Prehabilitation Adherence and Strategies.title: Adherence to prehabilitation in adult surgical patients: a systematic review, meta-analysis, meta-regression, and qualitative synthesis.
Prehabilitation Adherence and Strategies.author: N/A
Prehabilitation Adherence and Strategies.abstract_summary: This systematic review of 105 trials found that the average adherence to prehabilitation programs was 79%, but noted substantial inconsistency in how adherence was defined and reported. Only patient age was weakly associated with adherence, while qualitative analysis identified logistical issues and health conditions as barriers, and specialist supervision and personalization as facilitators. The authors call for standardized adherence metrics to improve the interpretation and design of prehabilitation studies.

Preoperative Exercise Testing.title: The usefulness of the modified steep ramp test as a practical exercise test for preoperative risk assessment in patients scheduled for pancreatic surgery.
Preoperative Exercise Testing.author: N/A
Preoperative Exercise Testing.abstract_summary: This study validated the modified steep ramp test (SRT) as a practical tool for assessing preoperative aerobic capacity in 48 patients undergoing pancreatic surgery. The SRT work rate strongly correlated with peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) from cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET). A performance below 2.1 W/kg on the SRT was identified as a useful cutoff to select patients for more detailed CPET evaluation or prehabilitation.

Perioperative Risk and Surgical Timing.title: Impact of daily, weekly, and seasonal surgical timing on postoperative outcomes in high-risk patients undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery: A retrospective, single-center study.
Perioperative Risk and Surgical Timing.author: N/A
Perioperative Risk and Surgical Timing.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of 14,394 high-risk patients found that afternoon surgeries were associated with higher long-term mortality and complication rates compared to morning surgeries. Specifically, surgeries starting between 3:00 and 6:00 p.m. carried the highest risk. The findings suggest that surgical start timing is a significant factor affecting postoperative outcomes in high-risk patients, highlighting the need for strategic scheduling.

Management of SGLT2 Inhibitors.title: Management of SGLT2i-associated perioperative ketoacidosis (SAPKA) / Euglycemic Diabetic Ketoacidosis (EDKA).
Management of SGLT2 Inhibitors.author: N/A
Management of SGLT2 Inhibitors.abstract_summary: This infographic provides a guide for anesthesia and surgery teams on the perioperative management of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i). It aims to mitigate the risk of SGLT2i-associated perioperative ketoacidosis (SAPKA), also known as euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (EDKA). The incidence of this complication is estimated at 0.17% for non-emergent and 1.1% for emergent procedures.

Preoperative Fasting Guidelines.title: Impact of liberal preoperative clear fluid fasting regimens on the risk of pulmonary aspiration in children (EUROFAST): an international prospective cohort study.
Preoperative Fasting Guidelines.author: N/A
Preoperative Fasting Guidelines.abstract_summary: This large international prospective cohort study of over 300,000 pediatric anesthetic procedures investigated the safety of liberalized clear fluid fasting times. The study found that reducing the fasting time from 2 hours to 1 hour or less (sip-til-send) was noninferior in terms of the incidence of confirmed pulmonary aspiration. These findings provide strong evidence supporting the safety of more liberal preoperative clear fluid fasting guidelines for children.

Perioperative Insulin Management.title: Development of insulin and its pharmacology and perioperative use: a narrative review.
Perioperative Insulin Management.author: N/A
Perioperative Insulin Management.abstract_summary: This narrative review details the evolution of insulin pharmacology, focusing on newer analogues and advanced delivery technologies like hybrid closed-loop systems. It provides essential considerations for the perioperative team in managing patients with diabetes using these modern insulins and devices. The goal is to ensure safe care and prevent complications in the surgical setting.

Neurobiology of Anesthetic-Induced Antin.title: General Anesthesia-activated Neurons in the Central Amygdala Mediate Antinociception: Distinct Roles in Acute versus Chronic Phases of Nerve Injury.
Neurobiology of Anesthetic-Induced Antin.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Anesthetic-Induced Antin.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of specific neurons in the central amygdala (CeA) that are activated by general anesthesia (CeAGA neurons) in mice. Researchers found these neurons have higher excitability and their activation produces antinociceptive effects in naïve mice and in the acute phase of nerve injury, but this effect diminishes in the chronic phase. The study suggests that KCC2 dysregulation in other CeA neurons contributes to the transition to chronic pain, highlighting the complex role of the CeA in pain modulation.

Comparative Effects of Sedatives on Memo.title: Effects of Sedative Doses of Propofol, Dexmedetomidine, and Fentanyl on Memory and Pain in Healthy Young Adults: A Randomized, Controlled, Single-blind Crossover Study Using Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging at 7 Tesla.
Comparative Effects of Sedatives on Memo.author: N/A
Comparative Effects of Sedatives on Memo.abstract_summary: This crossover study used 7T fMRI to examine how low doses of propofol, dexmedetomidine, and fentanyl affect memory and pain perception in healthy volunteers. Propofol significantly impaired next-day memory and reduced pain-related brain activation in key areas like the insula and amygdala. Dexmedetomidine and fentanyl showed some effects on memory-related activation but had less impact on pain ratings, revealing distinct neuroanatomic targets and cognitive effects for each drug.

Dexmedetomidine for Emergence Agitation.title: Peri-operative dexmedetomidine and emergence agitation in adults undergoing nasal surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Dexmedetomidine for Emergence Agitation.author: N/A
Dexmedetomidine for Emergence Agitation.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of nine randomized controlled trials assessed the effect of dexmedetomidine on emergence agitation in adults undergoing nasal surgery. The results showed that perioperative dexmedetomidine use significantly reduced the incidence of emergence agitation compared to placebo. Trial sequential analysis confirmed this finding, supporting the use of dexmedetomidine to mitigate this common postoperative complication.

Novel Anesthetic Agents and EEG Signatur.title: Comparative Electroencephalographic Profile of a New Anesthetic and Anticonvulsant That Is Selective for the GABA A R Slow Receptor Subtype.
Novel Anesthetic Agents and EEG Signatur.author: N/A
Novel Anesthetic Agents and EEG Signatur.abstract_summary: This study compared the EEG effects of a novel anesthetic, KSEB 01-S2, which selectively targets the GABAA R-slow receptor subtype, with the nonselective agonist propofol in rats. KSEB 01-S2 produced a unique EEG signature at loss of consciousness, characterized by a significant increase in theta power and a decrease in low gamma power, unlike propofol. This suggests a potential link between receptor subtype specificity and distinct EEG patterns during anesthesia.

Gabapentin for Postoperative Pain.title: Gabapentin for pain management following major surgery: a placebo controlled, double blind, randomized clinical trial (The GAP Study).
Gabapentin for Postoperative Pain.author: N/A
Gabapentin for Postoperative Pain.abstract_summary: This large, multicenter randomized controlled trial investigated the effectiveness of perioperative gabapentin in 1196 patients undergoing major cardiac, thoracic, or abdominal surgery. The study found that adding gabapentin to a multimodal analgesic regimen did not reduce the length of hospital stay. Furthermore, there were no significant differences in acute or chronic pain, opioid use, or serious adverse events compared to placebo.

Anesthetic Mechanisms and Amnesia.title: Anesthetic Amnesia: The Forgotten Importance of Forgetting?
Anesthetic Mechanisms and Amnesia.author: N/A
Anesthetic Mechanisms and Amnesia.abstract_summary: This article argues that the study of anesthetic-induced amnesia has been neglected compared to other components of anesthesia, despite evidence that loss of consciousness may sometimes be an illusion created by amnesia. It highlights that different anesthetics have varying amnestic potentials, dissociable from their hypnotic effects, and that there is no reliable real-time monitor for amnesia. The authors call for better understanding and management of anesthetic amnesia, particularly in relation to postoperative psychological distress.

Mitochondrial Targets of Anesthetics.title: Effects of the Quinone Analog Ubiquinone-5 on Murine Mitochondria and Hypnosis.
Mitochondrial Targets of Anesthetics.author: N/A
Mitochondrial Targets of Anesthetics.abstract_summary: This study investigated the anesthetic properties of ubiquinone-5 (Ub5), a short-chain coenzyme Q analog, in mice, hypothesizing it would act on mitochondria similarly to propofol. Researchers found that Ub5 induced hypnosis and EEG changes consistent with deep anesthesia by causing an uncompensated proton leak in mitochondria. The study identified the aspartate-glutamate carrier Aralar as a functional target, suggesting that mitochondrial proton leak is a key mechanism contributing to the hypnotic effects of some anesthetics.

Pharmacology of Non-Insulin Diabetes Med.title: Non-insulin diabetes medicines: a narrative review for anaesthetists and intensivists.
Pharmacology of Non-Insulin Diabetes Med.author: N/A
Pharmacology of Non-Insulin Diabetes Med.abstract_summary: This narrative review provides an overview of non-insulin diabetes medications for anesthetists and intensivists, covering classes such as biguanides, SGLT2 inhibitors, and newer incretin-based therapies. It focuses on their modes of action and provides critical considerations for the perioperative team. The aim is to ensure safe patient care and avoid complications associated with these agents in the surgical setting.

Dexmedetomidine and Lidocaine for Postop.title: Effect of dexamethasone and lidocaine combination on incidence of post-operative sore throat: A meta-analysis and trial sequential analysis.
Dexmedetomidine and Lidocaine for Postop.author: N/A
Dexmedetomidine and Lidocaine for Postop.abstract_summary: This meta-analysis of three randomized controlled trials investigated if combining intravenous dexamethasone and lidocaine is more effective than dexamethasone alone for preventing postoperative sore throat (POST). The results suggest a significant reduction in POST with the combination therapy, though it did not affect cough or hoarseness. While the authors recommend this cost-effective strategy, trial sequential analysis indicates that more research is needed to confirm the findings definitively.

Impact of Abortion Legislation on Anesth.title: Three Years On: The Impact of the Dobbs Decision on Anesthesia Practice.
Impact of Abortion Legislation on Anesth.author: N/A
Impact of Abortion Legislation on Anesth.abstract_summary: This article examines the consequences of the Dobbs decision on anesthesia practice three years after its implementation. It notes that patients seeking abortion care often present at later gestations with more comorbidities, impacting both patients and anesthesia providers. The authors suggest opportunities to improve health outcomes in this new legal landscape.

Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.title: Racial and Ethnic Differences in Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting Care.
Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.author: N/A
Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of over 60,000 cancer surgery patients investigated racial and ethnic differences in the administration of antiemetics. The findings revealed significant disparities, with Black patients being less likely to receive antiemetics preoperatively, intraoperatively, and in the recovery room compared to patients of other racial or ethnic groups. These results suggest systemic differences in care that may contribute to health inequities.

Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.title: Association between race, ethnicity, and surgical case cancellations: A retrospective study in a cohort of patients undergoing oncological surgeries.
Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.author: N/A
Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Care.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of over 100,000 surgical cases at a cancer center found that Black patients had a significantly higher rate of surgical cancellations compared to White and Asian patients. After adjusting for confounders, Black patients still had higher odds of cancellation. The findings suggest that racial and ethnic disparities exist in surgical care pathways, highlighting a need to address the underlying causes.

Gender Equity and Leadership in Anesthes.title: The Glass Ceiling in Global Health: Perspectives of Female and Male Anesthesiologists.
Gender Equity and Leadership in Anesthes.author: N/A
Gender Equity and Leadership in Anesthes.abstract_summary: This international survey of anesthesiologists explored gender differences in perceived barriers to global health careers and leadership roles. A significantly higher proportion of women (70%) than men (48.6%) agreed that women face unique barriers, including work-family balance, lack of mentorship, and gender-based discrimination. The study underscores the need for policies promoting work-life balance, mentorship, and equal opportunities to improve gender equity in global health leadership.

Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.title: Head Strikes Among Perioperative Personnel in the United States: A Mixed Methods Study.
Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.author: N/A
Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.abstract_summary: This national survey of over 1,800 anesthesiologists and perioperative nurses reveals that head strikes from equipment are a common but severely underreported occupational hazard, with 78.5% of respondents experiencing at least one in the past year. Key causes include equipment placement and time pressure, while barriers to reporting include time constraints and fear of negative consequences. The study calls for multifaceted interventions to improve workspace safety and reporting culture.

Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.title: "The pain and suffering are just too great for me to manage": A qualitative study of emotional distress among anesthesiologists after challenging clinical events.
Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.author: N/A
Occupational Hazards and Clinician Wellb.abstract_summary: This qualitative study interviewed 20 anesthesiology faculty members to explore the sources and long-term effects of emotional distress following challenging clinical events. Risk factors included clinical errors, unexpected outcomes, lack of support, and patient-related factors like young age. Participants reported profound and lasting impacts such as guilt, shame, self-doubt, and flashbacks, highlighting the need for interventions to support anesthesiologists' mental health.

Sustainability of Patient Warming Device.title: Sustainability assessment of perioperative patient warming devices: a comparative life cycle assessment and costing.
Sustainability of Patient Warming Device.author: N/A
Sustainability of Patient Warming Device.abstract_summary: This study conducted a life cycle assessment and cost analysis of three active warming devices and passive warming with flannel blankets. The resistive blanket was found to have the lowest environmental and economic impacts. The authors conclude that perioperative patient warming sustainability can be optimized by using resistive blankets for active warming and minimizing the use of disposable consumables and flannel blankets.

Management of Electronic Health Record (.title: Continuing Anesthesia Services in the Face of a Prolonged Digital Health System Outage.
Management of Electronic Health Record (.author: N/A
Management of Electronic Health Record (.abstract_summary: This narrative review details a pediatric anesthesiology department's response to a prolonged electronic health record (EHR) system outage. The authors describe how the outage affected all aspects of care, from patient identification to OR scheduling and communication. The review provides operational recommendations for maintaining safe, high-quality care and financial sustainability during similar digital health system failures.

Breath Analysis for Anesthetic Monitorin.title: Breath Analysis of Propofol and Associated Metabolic Signatures: A Pilot Study Using Secondary Electrospray Ionization-High-resolution Mass Spectrometry.
Breath Analysis for Anesthetic Monitorin.author: N/A
Breath Analysis for Anesthetic Monitorin.abstract_summary: This pilot study in 10 pediatric patients demonstrated that real-time breath analysis can accurately reflect serum propofol concentrations. The analysis also detected metabolic changes, such as increased fatty aldehydes, suggesting oxidative stress associated with surgery. These findings highlight the potential of exhaled-breath pharmacometabolomics as a non-invasive tool for personalizing anesthetic care and monitoring perioperative metabolic responses.

Wearable Sensors for Opioid Dependence M.title: Developing a Wearable Sensor-Based Digital Biomarker of Opioid Dependence.
Wearable Sensors for Opioid Dependence M.author: N/A
Wearable Sensors for Opioid Dependence M.abstract_summary: This study aimed to develop a digital biomarker for opioid dependence using wearable sensor data from 41 participants with acute pain. By comparing opioid-naive and chronic opioid users, researchers developed machine learning models that could predict a patient's opioid use status with 70-90% accuracy. The differentiating physiologic features may detect opioid dependence, suggesting that wearable sensors could become a novel tool for safer opioid prescribing.

Hypotension Prediction Models.title: Predicting arterial pressure without prejudice: towards effective hypotension prediction models.
Hypotension Prediction Models.author: N/A
Hypotension Prediction Models.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study on deep learning models for predicting hypotension, highlighting the issue of selection bias in training data. The authors note that unbiased data allowed an algorithm to learn more than just current blood pressure, whereas biased data distorted and inflated the model's positive predictive value. The piece offers suggestions for developing more effective and unbiased hypotension prediction algorithms for clinical use.

Hypotension Prediction Models.title: Mean arterial pressure is all you need in a machine learning model for mean arterial pressure prediction.
Hypotension Prediction Models.author: N/A
Hypotension Prediction Models.abstract_summary: This retrospective study evaluated whether machine learning models could predict a drop in mean arterial pressure (MAP) below 65 mmHg using only previous MAP values as input. Using data from three large databases, the models achieved high accuracy (ROC AUCs up to 0.963 for a 5-minute prediction horizon). The study concludes that predicting future hypotension is possible using simple MAP input, which could allow clinicians to intervene proactively.

Continuous Glucose Monitoring.title: Accuracy of continuous glucose monitoring during noncardiac surgery: a prospective, blinded observational multicentre cohort study.
Continuous Glucose Monitoring.author: N/A
Continuous Glucose Monitoring.abstract_summary: This prospective multicenter study assessed the accuracy of a continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) device in 118 patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Comparing CGM readings to arterial blood glucose, the study found an overall bias of 0.38 mM, which decreased as the perioperative period progressed. With over 98% of values falling within acceptable risk ranges, the study concludes that modern CGM is sufficiently accurate for perioperative use and could improve surveillance of dysglycemia.

AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.title: Technology, evidence, and continuing clinical education: a role for self-directed learning?
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.author: N/A
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.abstract_summary: This article discusses the challenge for clinicians to keep up with rapidly advancing clinical technology in anesthesia. It highlights self-directed learning using videos as an effective and flexible training method. However, it suggests that this approach is unlikely to completely replace traditional instructor-led learning for new equipment.

AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.title: Leveraging Large Language Models to Enhance Emotional Intelligence Training in Anesthesiology.
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.author: N/A
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.abstract_summary: This article proposes using Large Language Models (LLMs) as a tool to enhance emotional intelligence training for anesthesiologists. LLMs can generate diverse, on-demand simulation scenarios for practicing emotionally charged conversations, such as addressing patient concerns or resolving conflicts. While not a replacement for human interaction, LLMs can serve as accessible supplemental tools to bolster communication skills when integrated with expert oversight.

AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.title: Perioperative autonomic nervous system imbalance on surgical outcomes: a systematic literature review.
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.author: N/A
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.abstract_summary: This systematic review explores how perioperative autonomic nervous system (ANS) imbalance, characterized by sympathetic hyperactivation, contributes to adverse surgical outcomes like infections and neurocognitive decline. It discusses how factors like surgical trauma and anesthesia drive this imbalance. The review also covers pharmacological and nonpharmacological strategies to restore ANS balance, highlighting its potential to improve patient recovery.

AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.title: Using AI chatbots as clinical decision support for regional anesthesia: is the new era of "e-Consults" ready for primetime?
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.author: N/A
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.abstract_summary: This pilot study evaluated four popular large language model (LLM) chatbots as clinical decision support tools for regional anesthesiology. When prompted with basic and complex clinical scenarios, all platforms showed weaknesses in clinical judgment, thoroughness, and rationale, including instances of confabulation. The study concludes that current LLM-based chatbots are not yet reliable for assisting in real-world regional anesthesia clinical decision-making.

AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.title: Artificial intelligence and regional anesthesiology education curriculum development: navigating the digital noise.
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.author: N/A
AI in Anesthesia Education and Practice.abstract_summary: This article discusses the potential of artificial intelligence (AI), particularly large language models, to revolutionize curriculum development in regional anesthesiology education. AI can help create targeted and individualized content for learners at various training stages, addressing common challenges in academic medicine. The authors emphasize the need for careful evaluation and monitoring to ensure optimal implementation of this technology in an educational context.

Quantitative EEG Monitoring.title: Response of the Conox quantitative electroencephalographic monitor to neuromuscular block in awake volunteers.
Quantitative EEG Monitoring.author: N/A
Quantitative EEG Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study tested the Conox monitor's reliability in awake, paralyzed volunteers by replaying their EEGs. The results showed that both the qCON and qNOX indices decreased to levels indicating sedation or anesthesia, despite the subjects being fully awake. The study concludes that the Conox monitor requires muscle activity (EMG) to generate accurate values in awake individuals and may be unreliable in paralyzed patients.

Quantitative EEG Monitoring.title: Electroencephalographic changes related to cortico-subcortical decoupling during propofol-induced loss of consciousness: A secondary analysis of a prospective observational study.
Quantitative EEG Monitoring.author: N/A
Quantitative EEG Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study analyzed artifact-corrected EEG data from healthy volunteers during propofol-induced loss of consciousness (LOC) to correspond with fMRI findings of cortico-subcortical decoupling. Researchers found that decoupling at LOC coincides with a gradual decrease in the qCON index and a significant increase in frontal alpha power. These findings help bridge the gap between advanced fMRI research and practical bedside EEG monitoring.

Remote Continuous Monitoring.title: Remote Continuous Vital Sign Monitoring of Scoliosis Surgery Patients on General Wards: A Cost-Effectiveness Analysis.
Remote Continuous Monitoring.author: N/A
Remote Continuous Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the cost-effectiveness of a 24-hour remote continuous monitoring service (HIVE) for scoliosis surgery patients on general wards, who would otherwise require ICU/HDU admission. Comparing pre- and post-implementation cohorts, the HIVE service was associated with a reduction of 27.1 ICU hours and AU$2682 in healthcare costs per patient, without increasing complications. The findings provide strong economic evidence for the value of remote monitoring in this patient group.

Continuous Hemoglobin Monitoring.title: Continuous and Noninvasive Total Blood Hemoglobin Measurement Using Near-Infrared Reflectance Spectrometry.
Continuous Hemoglobin Monitoring.author: N/A
Continuous Hemoglobin Monitoring.abstract_summary: This study evaluated a novel, noninvasive total hemoglobin (tHb) measurement algorithm based on near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) in 189 cardiac surgery patients. The NIRS-based tHb measurements showed good agreement with invasive blood gas tHb values, with a bias of 0.08 g/dL and a concordance of 86.1%. The results suggest this technology could provide accurate, continuous tHb monitoring to guide transfusion practices during surgery.

Non-Invasive Hemorrhage Detection.title: A prospective, observational study of non-invasive venous waveform analysis (NIVA) for the detection of acute low volume blood loss in humans.
Non-Invasive Hemorrhage Detection.author: N/A
Non-Invasive Hemorrhage Detection.abstract_summary: This prospective study assessed a novel Non-Invasive Venous waveform Analysis (NIVA) technology for detecting low-volume blood loss in 33 blood donors. The system's output, the IntraVAscular Number (IVAN), showed a significant decrease after just 200 mL of blood loss. The technology demonstrated high accuracy (AUC of 0.91) for detecting 500 mL of blood loss, suggesting its potential as an early, non-invasive monitor for acute hemorrhage.

Facial Pain Recognition Models.title: Application of deep learning-based facial pain recognition model for postoperative pain assessment.
Facial Pain Recognition Models.author: N/A
Facial Pain Recognition Models.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a deep learning model to assess postoperative pain by analyzing facial expressions from clinical and simulated datasets. The model showed high performance in identifying severe pain, with AUROC values of 0.898 in the clinical dataset. Based on these results, a facial pain recognition software was created, offering a new tool for real-time, objective pain monitoring, especially for patients with communication difficulties.

Tracheal Extubation Practices.title: Impact of tracheal extubation location after surgical procedures on peri-operative times: a prospective dual-centre observational study.
Tracheal Extubation Practices.author: N/A
Tracheal Extubation Practices.abstract_summary: This prospective observational study compared operating theatre (OT) versus post-anaesthesia care unit (PACU) extubation in 756 patients. Extubating in the OT was associated with an 8-minute increase in theatre occupancy time. However, it was also linked to a lower incidence of postoperative desaturation and hypotension, suggesting a potential trade-off between efficiency and patient safety.

Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.title: Incidence of transient sinus pause in cardiac rhythm increases with the use of hyperangulated videolaryngoscope blade compared to standard angle blade during tracheal intubation: A prospective randomised controlled trial.
Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.author: N/A
Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared hyperangulated and standard angle videolaryngoscope blades during intubation in 134 patients. The use of a hyperangulated blade was associated with a significantly higher incidence of transient sinus pause (19% vs. 4%). The study identifies the hyperangulated blade as an independent predictor for this adverse event, likely due to different forces exerted on the larynx.

Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.title: Videolaryngoscopy versus direct laryngoscopy for teaching direct laryngoscopy skills: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.author: N/A
Videolaryngoscopy in Airway Management.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 10 studies assessed whether using a Macintosh-style videolaryngoscope is effective for teaching direct laryngoscopy. The findings show that videolaryngoscopy training led to a higher first-attempt success rate compared to direct laryngoscopy training, with no difference in overall success or time to intubation. The authors conclude that videolaryngoscopy is an effective teaching tool and should be considered for this purpose.

Airway Topicalization in Children.title: Consensus recommendations for paediatric airway topicalisation using lidocaine.
Airway Topicalization in Children.author: N/A
Airway Topicalization in Children.abstract_summary: An international expert group developed consensus recommendations for using lidocaine for airway topicalization in children due to a lack of existing guidance. Following a systematic literature review and a Delphi process, 21 recommendations were agreed upon across five domains, including dosing and safety. Despite limited high-grade evidence, these expert-driven guidelines aim to promote safer clinical practice.

Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Childr.title: 'The trachea heals but the hypoxia does not' an emergency front-of-neck access in a 4-year-old with foreign body airway obstruction.
Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Childr.author: N/A
Emergency Front-of-Neck Access in Childr.abstract_summary: This case report describes a life-threatening 'Can't Intubate Can't Oxygenate' (CICO) situation in a 4-year-old child with a foreign body airway obstruction. The report details the successful use of an emergency front-of-neck surgical airway (eFONA) via a scalpel-bougie-tube method during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. This highlights a critical intervention for a rare but potentially fatal event in the pediatric population.

High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.title: High-Flow Nasal Oxygen versus Mechanical Ventilation Through a Laryngeal Mask During General Anesthesia Without Muscle Paralysis: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.author: N/A
High-Flow Nasal Oxygen vs. Laryngeal Mas.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) to laryngeal mask ventilation in 180 patients undergoing short general anesthesia without muscle paralysis. HFNO was found to be noninferior, with a 99% success rate in both groups for maintaining adequate oxygenation. While HFNO was associated with fewer postoperative respiratory symptoms, it also led to higher intraoperative carbon dioxide levels, underscoring the need for careful patient selection and monitoring.

Mechanisms of Isoflurane-Induced Neuroco.title: Direct inhibition of cystathionine-beta-synthase by isoflurane contributes to delayed neurocognitive recovery after isoflurane general anaesthesia in mice.
Mechanisms of Isoflurane-Induced Neuroco.author: N/A
Mechanisms of Isoflurane-Induced Neuroco.abstract_summary: This study in mice investigated the mechanism behind isoflurane-induced perioperative neurocognitive disorders (PND). Researchers found that isoflurane directly inhibits the enzyme cystathionine-beta-synthase (CBS), leading to homocysteine accumulation in the brain and a persistent decline in cognitive function. Activating CBS or supplementing its product, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), accelerated cognitive recovery, providing novel insights into PND and potential therapeutic targets.

Anesthetic Neurotoxicity and the Gut-Bra.title: Gut Microbiota Influences Developmental Anesthetic Neurotoxicity in Neonatal Rats.
Anesthetic Neurotoxicity and the Gut-Bra.author: N/A
Anesthetic Neurotoxicity and the Gut-Bra.abstract_summary: This study in neonatal rats investigated the role of gut microbiota in sevoflurane-induced neurodevelopmental impairment. Repeated sevoflurane exposure altered the gut microbiota composition and caused spatial learning disabilities. Fecal microbiota transplantation from healthy rats improved these learning deficits, increased beneficial bacteria and butyrate concentration, and suppressed neuroinflammation, suggesting that modulating the gut microbiota could be a prophylactic strategy against developmental anesthetic neurotoxicity.

Genetic Factors in Anesthetic Requiremen.title: Clinical and Genetic Factors Associated with Intraoperative Minimum Alveolar Concentration Ratio: A Single-center Retrospective Cohort and Genome-wide Association Study.
Genetic Factors in Anesthetic Requiremen.author: N/A
Genetic Factors in Anesthetic Requiremen.abstract_summary: This large retrospective study of over 30,000 cases investigated factors associated with the clinically delivered dose of volatile anesthetics (MAC ratio). The study confirmed that mean arterial pressure was a significant factor, and also identified demographic and procedural covariates, noting that female patients received lower doses despite evidence of higher requirements. A genome-wide association study suggested several plausible genes, including DISC1, which is linked to sleep/wake patterns and brain activity under isoflurane.

Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.title: Impact of desflurane removal from the operating room on carbon dioxide emissions at a tertiary academic medical centre: a retrospective analysis.
Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.author: N/A
Environmental Impact of Inhaled Anesthet.abstract_summary: This retrospective analysis at a major US academic medical center quantified the environmental impact of eliminating desflurane. Between 2014 and 2022, CO2 equivalent emissions per patient decreased by 82.8%, with the removal of desflurane being a major contributor, resulting in an annual reduction of approximately 900 metric tonnes. After desflurane's elimination, the use of nitrous oxide and high fresh gas flows emerged as the dominant remaining sources of emissions.

Intergenerational Effects of Anesthetics.title: Intergenerational Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder in a Rat Model: Initiating Mechanisms and Pharmacological Prevention.
Intergenerational Effects of Anesthetics.author: N/A
Intergenerational Effects of Anesthetics.abstract_summary: This study in rats explored whether sevoflurane-induced neurocognitive deficits could be passed to the next generation. Male rats exposed to sevoflurane developed hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis upregulation, inflammation, and behavioral deficits, which were prevented by an NKCC1 inhibitor or a glucocorticoid receptor inhibitor. Importantly, the male offspring of the exposed rats also exhibited similar neurocognitive deficits, suggesting an intergenerational transmission of PND vulnerability that could be pharmacologically prevented.

Remimazolam in Pediatric Sedation.title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Remimazolam for Procedural Sedation in Children and Adolescents.
Remimazolam in Pediatric Sedation.author: N/A
Remimazolam in Pediatric Sedation.abstract_summary: This study investigated the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of remimazolam for procedural sedation in patients aged 6 to 18. The results showed that remimazolam's pharmacokinetics in children differ from size-corrected adult data, and the existing dosing regimen was often insufficient to achieve adequate sedation. The authors propose an optimized, higher per-kilogram dosing regimen to improve the effectiveness of remimazolam in this population.

Remimazolam vs. Propofol in Geriatric Su.title: Incidence of postoperative delirium and quality of recovery in older patients undergoing gastrectomy under general anaesthesia with remimazolam vs. propofol: a randomised non-inferiority study.
Remimazolam vs. Propofol in Geriatric Su.author: N/A
Remimazolam vs. Propofol in Geriatric Su.abstract_summary: This randomized non-inferiority trial compared remimazolam and propofol for maintenance of general anesthesia in 432 older patients undergoing gastrectomy. The incidence of postoperative delirium within 72 hours was identical in both groups (7.9%). Quality of recovery scores at 24 hours were also similar, concluding that remimazolam is a viable alternative to propofol in this patient population regarding these outcomes.

Neurobiology of Propofol Anesthesia.title: The role of supramammillary nucleus glutamatergic neurons in modulating consciousness transitions during propofol anesthesia in mice.
Neurobiology of Propofol Anesthesia.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Propofol Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This study in mice investigated the role of glutamatergic neurons in the supramammillary nucleus (SuM) in propofol anesthesia. Their activity decreased before loss of consciousness and increased upon recovery, and manipulating these neurons altered anesthesia induction and emergence times. The findings demonstrate that SuM glutamatergic neurons, and their projections to the medial septum, are crucial for regulating consciousness transitions during propofol anesthesia.

Propofol vs. Sevoflurane on Postoperativ.title: Propofol versus sevoflurane anesthesia on postoperative sleep quality in older patients after major abdominal surgery: A randomized clinical trial.
Propofol vs. Sevoflurane on Postoperativ.author: N/A
Propofol vs. Sevoflurane on Postoperativ.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared propofol-based versus sevoflurane-based anesthesia on postoperative sleep in 144 older patients undergoing major abdominal surgery. The propofol group had a significantly longer total sleep time on the first postoperative night compared to the sevoflurane group. This difference may be partly explained by lower plasma orexin-A concentrations in the propofol group.

Novel Reversal Agents.title: Efficacy and safety of adamgammadex for reversing rocuronium-induced deep neuromuscular block: a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, positive-controlled phase III trial.
Novel Reversal Agents.author: N/A
Novel Reversal Agents.abstract_summary: This phase III noninferiority trial compared a new reversal agent, adamgammadex, with sugammadex for reversing deep rocuronium-induced neuromuscular block in 321 patients. Adamgammadex (8 mg/kg) was noninferior to sugammadex (4 mg/kg) in achieving a train-of-four ratio of 0.9 within 10 minutes, with a success rate of 98.7% vs. 100%. The safety profiles of the two drugs were similar, establishing adamgammadex as a viable alternative.

Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Sugammadex versus Neostigmine for Reversal of Rocuronium on Gastric Emptying in Adults Undergoing Elective Colorectal Surgery.
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.author: N/A
Sugammadex vs. Neostigmine.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared sugammadex and neostigmine-glycopyrrolate on gastric emptying after colorectal surgery. While there was no difference in the primary outcome of gastric emptying, sugammadex was associated with a significantly shorter time to first bowel movement and faster reversal of neuromuscular blockade. The study suggests a potential role for sugammadex in enhanced recovery protocols, though further research is needed.

Immunological Effects of Sugammadex.title: The immunomodulatory effect of sugammadex in vitro and after total hip arthroplasty : A randomised controlled pilot and retrospective cohort study.
Immunological Effects of Sugammadex.author: N/A
Immunological Effects of Sugammadex.abstract_summary: This study investigated the potential immunomodulatory effects of sugammadex through in-vitro, pilot RCT, and retrospective cohort analyses. In vitro, sugammadex restored cytokine production suppressed by rocuronium. However, the clinical studies found no evidence of early postoperative immunomodulatory effects or association with infectious complications at clinically used doses.

Deep vs. Moderate Neuromuscular Blockade.title: Deep versus Moderate Neuromuscular Blockade During Total Hip Replacement Surgery on Postoperative Recovery and Immune Function: A Randomized Controlled Trial.
Deep vs. Moderate Neuromuscular Blockade.author: N/A
Deep vs. Moderate Neuromuscular Blockade.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared deep versus moderate neuromuscular blockade (NMB) in 100 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study found no difference in the primary outcome of quality of recovery (QoR-40 score) on postoperative day 1. There were also no significant differences in postoperative inflammation or pain scores, suggesting no clear benefit of deep NMB over moderate NMB for this type of surgery.

Recovery of Hypoxic Ventilatory Response.title: Recovery of the acute hypoxic ventilatory response after reversal of a minimal neuromuscular block. A randomized, controlled trial in healthy, non-obese volunteers.
Recovery of Hypoxic Ventilatory Response.author: N/A
Recovery of Hypoxic Ventilatory Response.abstract_summary: This study in healthy volunteers examined the recovery of the acute hypoxic ventilatory response (AHVR) after minimal neuromuscular blockade. It found that even after symptoms resolved, AHVR remained depressed in a considerable proportion of volunteers, whether they recovered spontaneously or with sugammadex. While fewer patients had residual depression after sugammadex reversal, the overall recovery of AHVR did not significantly differ between groups, highlighting a prolonged subclinical effect of neuromuscular blockade.

Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.title: Regional anaesthesia modalities for primary total hip arthroplasty: a systematic review and component network meta-analysis.
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.author: N/A
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.abstract_summary: This network meta-analysis of 87 randomized controlled trials compared various single-shot regional anesthesia techniques for total hip arthroplasty. Combined modalities, particularly pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block plus local infiltrative analgesia (LIA), were found to be most favorable. This combination resulted in lower pain scores, reduced opioid consumption, and motor-sparing effects in the early postoperative period.

Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.title: Comparison of two peripheral regional analgesic techniques for primary elective total hip arthroplasty: a randomised clinical trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.author: N/A
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared two motor-sparing regional techniques for total hip arthroplasty: an 'anterior' approach (pericapsular nerve group and lateral femoral cutaneous nerve blocks) versus a 'posterior' approach (erector spinae plane block). The study found no clinically or statistically significant difference in 24-hour morphine consumption or other secondary outcomes between the two groups. The choice of block may therefore depend on patient and situational factors.

Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.title: Pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block compared to intrathecal morphine for analgesic efficacy in total hip arthroplasty: A placebo-controlled randomized double-blind non-inferiority trial.
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.author: N/A
Regional Anesthesia for Total Hip Arthro.abstract_summary: This non-inferiority trial compared the pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block to intrathecal morphine for pain control after total hip arthroplasty. The study found that the PENG block was non-inferior to intrathecal morphine for maximum pain scores and 48-hour opioid consumption. Importantly, the PENG block did not cause additional motor function compromise, making it a viable analgesic alternative.

Complications of Intrathecal Morphine.title: Pulmonary complications after intrathecal morphine administration: a systematic review and meta-analysis with meta-regression and trial sequential analysis.
Complications of Intrathecal Morphine.author: N/A
Complications of Intrathecal Morphine.abstract_summary: This meta-analysis of 127 trials examined the risk of pulmonary complications with intrathecal morphine in non-obstetric surgery. The study found no significant increase in sedation or hypoxemia, but a higher rate of respiratory depression, particularly with doses >500 mcg. The evidence quality was very low for respiratory depression, suggesting further research is needed to clarify the risk profile of intrathecal morphine.

Blocks for Hip Fracture Pain Management.title: Comparing the pericapsular nerve group block and fascia iliaca block for acute pain management in patients with hip fracture: a randomised clinical trial.
Blocks for Hip Fracture Pain Management.author: N/A
Blocks for Hip Fracture Pain Management.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared the pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block with the fascia iliaca block (FIB) for acute pain in 64 hip fracture patients. The PENG block provided superior analgesia within the first hour, with a significantly greater reduction in pain intensity and more patients achieving substantial pain relief. The findings suggest the PENG block is a promising modality for acute pain management in this setting.

Blocks for Breast Surgery.title: Erector spinae plane block versus paravertebral block for major oncological breast surgery: a multicentre randomised controlled trial.
Blocks for Breast Surgery.author: N/A
Blocks for Breast Surgery.abstract_summary: This multicenter randomized trial compared erector spinae plane block (ESPB) to thoracic paravertebral block (PVB) for pain management after major breast cancer surgery in 292 women. ESPB did not meet noninferiority criteria, was associated with higher pain scores, and provided less reliable dermatomal coverage than PVB. The study concludes that PVB remains the preferred regional technique for major breast surgery.

Sensory-Selective Local Anesthetics.title: Sensory-selective peripheral and neuraxial nerve blockade with 2',6'-pipecolylxylidine.
Sensory-Selective Local Anesthetics.author: N/A
Sensory-Selective Local Anesthetics.abstract_summary: This study describes the properties of 2',6'-pipecolylxylidine (PPX), a metabolite of amino-amide local anesthetics, in rats. PPX was found to provide sensory-selective local and neuraxial nerve blockade, producing sensory block without motor block. The study also demonstrated a favorable safety profile compared to ropivacaine, suggesting PPX has potential as a novel sensory-selective local anesthetic for pain management.

Education in Regional Anesthesia.title: Training and assessment of skills in neuraxial space access: a scoping review of educational approaches to lumbar puncture, epidural anaesthesia, and spinal anaesthesia.
Education in Regional Anesthesia.author: N/A
Education in Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This scoping review analyzed 99 studies on training and assessment for neuraxial procedures like lumbar puncture, spinal, and epidural anesthesia. The review found significant variation in educational methods and that most studies were of low methodological quality. It concludes that while simulation-based training appears to enhance skills and confidence, higher-quality research is needed to link training approaches to patient outcomes.

Education in Regional Anesthesia.title: Aspiring to mastery clinical skills learning in regional anaesthesia.
Education in Regional Anesthesia.author: N/A
Education in Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This article discusses the concept of mastery learning for acquiring complex technical skills in regional anesthesia. It explains that a structured program aimed at achieving a high level of performance leads to better learning and clinical outcomes. The authors also explore how emerging technologies may influence future skill acquisition in this field.

Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.title: Unilateral subcostal anterior quadratus lumborum block versus intrathecal morphine for postoperative pain in laparoscopic nephrectomy: a randomized controlled trial.
Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.author: N/A
Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared unilateral anterior subcostal quadratus lumborum (QL) block to intrathecal morphine (ITM) for pain control after laparoscopic nephrectomy. The QL block was not non-inferior to ITM regarding 24-hour opioid consumption, and patients receiving ITM had lower pain scores and higher satisfaction. The authors suggest QL block may be an option for patients at risk for ITM-related side effects but note its lower efficacy may be due to inconsistent cranial spread.

Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.title: No quadriceps muscle weakness following anterior quadratus lumborum block compared with placebo: a randomized, non-inferiority, blinded, volunteer trial.
Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.author: N/A
Anterior Quadratus Lumborum Block.abstract_summary: This randomized, triple-blind trial in 20 healthy volunteers investigated whether a unilateral anterior quadratus lumborum (QL) block causes quadriceps muscle weakness. The study found no significant difference in quadriceps strength between the active block with ropivacaine and a placebo block, demonstrating non-inferiority. The findings suggest that the anterior QL block is motor-sparing and can be safely used in procedures requiring early postoperative mobilization.

Blocks for Inguinal Hernia Repair.title: Efficacy of laparoscopic-installed rectus sheath block for postoperative pain reduction in transabdominal preperitoneal inguinal hernia repair: a double-blind, randomised-controlled trial.
Blocks for Inguinal Hernia Repair.author: N/A
Blocks for Inguinal Hernia Repair.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated the effectiveness of a laparoscopically-guided rectus sheath block for postoperative pain after inguinal hernia repair. The study included 35 patients and found no significant difference in postoperative pain scores or opioid requirements between the intervention group and the control group. The results suggest that this block does not provide an additional analgesic benefit in this surgical context.

Blocks for Orthognathic Surgery.title: Bilateral ultrasound-guided maxillary and mandibular combined nerves block reduces morphine consumption after double-jaw orthognathic surgery: a randomized controlled trial.
Blocks for Orthognathic Surgery.author: N/A
Blocks for Orthognathic Surgery.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial in 50 patients found that a bilateral ultrasound-guided block of the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) nerves significantly reduced postoperative opioid consumption after double-jaw orthognathic surgery compared to local infiltration. Opioid consumption was reduced by about 50% on postoperative days 1 and 2. The study also noted a correlation between preoperative anxiety and higher postoperative pain and opioid use.

General vs. Regional Anesthesia for TJA.title: Regional versus general anesthesia for total hip and knee arthroplasty: a nationwide retrospective cohort study.
General vs. Regional Anesthesia for TJA.author: N/A
General vs. Regional Anesthesia for TJA.abstract_summary: This large nationwide retrospective cohort study from South Korea compared outcomes of over 500,000 patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty with either regional (RA) or general anesthesia (GA). After propensity score matching, RA was associated with significantly lower 30-day and 90-day mortality rates compared to GA. However, there was no significant difference in the overall postoperative complication rate between the two groups.

Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.title: Impact of superficial and deep parasternal blocks on recovery after cardiac surgery with sternotomy: a randomised controlled trial.
Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.author: N/A
Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial assessed whether superficial or deep parasternal intercostal plane blocks improve postoperative quality of recovery after cardiac surgery compared to standard care. In 254 patients, neither block significantly improved Quality of Recovery-15 scores at 24 hours. Additionally, pain scores and analgesic consumption were similar across all groups, suggesting limited benefit of these blocks for this indication.

Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.title: Maximum extension and regression rate of cutaneous sensory block: superficial vs. deep parasternal intercostal plane blocks in patients undergoing open cardiac surgery.
Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.author: N/A
Parasternal Blocks for Cardiac Surgery.abstract_summary: This prospective study compared the sensory block characteristics of superficial (S-PIP) and deep (D-PIP) parasternal intercostal plane blocks in 30 cardiac surgery patients. Both blocks provided comparable and extensive sensory coverage of the anterior thorax, primarily from T2-T6, with no significant differences in the extent of blockade at 30 minutes. The study also found no differences in postoperative opioid consumption or pain scores between the two techniques.

Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) Block Im.title: Pericapsular nerve group block: a 3D CT scan imaging study to determine the spread of injectate.
Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) Block Im.author: N/A
Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) Block Im.abstract_summary: This study used 3D CT imaging to visualize the spread of injectate after a pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block in 10 patients undergoing hip surgery. The injectate was primarily confined to the epimysium of the iliacus and psoas muscles, with minimal spread to the hip capsule and no spread to the obturator foramen. This suggests the analgesic effect of the PENG block is likely due to blocking femoral nerve branches within the iliopsoas muscle rather than the obturator nerve.

Predicting Fluid Responsiveness.title: Context-specific clinical applicability of the end-expiratory occlusion test to predict fluid responsiveness in mechanically ventilated patients: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Predicting Fluid Responsiveness.author: N/A
Predicting Fluid Responsiveness.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 24 studies evaluated the end-expiratory occlusion test (EEOT) for predicting fluid responsiveness in mechanically ventilated patients. The EEOT performed acceptably well overall, particularly in the ICU setting, with a pooled sensitivity of 0.87 and specificity of 0.90. However, its performance was notably lower in the operating room, highlighting the need for context-specific assessments of fluid responsiveness.

Postoperative Iron Therapy.title: The use of iron after surgery: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Postoperative Iron Therapy.author: N/A
Postoperative Iron Therapy.abstract_summary: This meta-analysis of 15 randomized controlled trials evaluated the efficacy of postoperative iron therapy for anemia after major surgery. Intravenous iron administered within 30 days of surgery was effective at increasing hemoglobin levels. In contrast, oral iron showed no benefit, suggesting that IV iron is the preferred route for treating postoperative anemia.

Hemodynamic-Guided Fluid Management.title: A dynamic elastance-based protocol to guide intra-operative fluid management in major abdominal surgery: A randomised clinical trial.
Hemodynamic-Guided Fluid Management.author: N/A
Hemodynamic-Guided Fluid Management.abstract_summary: This randomized trial tested a fluid management protocol based on dynamic arterial elastance (Eadyn) during major abdominal surgery. While the protocol did not reduce postoperative lactate levels, the Eadyn group received more vasopressors and had a lower fluid balance. The study suggests that an Eadyn-guided approach can lead to a more restrictive fluid strategy.

Fibrinogen Replacement in Neonatal Cardi.title: Effect of In Vivo Administration of Fibrinogen Concentrate Versus Cryoprecipitate on Ex Vivo Clot Degradation in Neonates Undergoing Cardiac Surgery.
Fibrinogen Replacement in Neonatal Cardi.author: N/A
Fibrinogen Replacement in Neonatal Cardi.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared fibrinogen concentrate to cryoprecipitate for hemostasis in neonates undergoing cardiac surgery. Neonates receiving fibrinogen concentrate had similar perioperative clot degradation, required significantly fewer post-CPB blood transfusions, and had no increase in bleeding or thrombotic complications. The findings suggest fibrinogen concentrate is a safe and effective alternative that may reduce transfusion needs in this high-risk population.

Management of Diabetes in Pregnancy.title: Diabetes Mellitus in Pregnancy: Implications for Obstetric Anesthesia.
Management of Diabetes in Pregnancy.author: N/A
Management of Diabetes in Pregnancy.abstract_summary: This review provides a comprehensive overview of the implications of diabetes for obstetric anesthesia. It covers peripartum insulin management, the use of technologies like continuous glucose monitors, and strategies for recognizing and managing euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. The article emphasizes the anesthesiologist's crucial role in managing this common comorbidity to ensure maternal and fetal safety.

Obstetric Anesthesia Practice Trends.title: Obstetric Anesthesia Workforce Survey: Forty-year Update.
Obstetric Anesthesia Practice Trends.author: N/A
Obstetric Anesthesia Practice Trends.abstract_summary: This survey, a 40-year update on the obstetric anesthesia workforce, reveals a 50% decrease in the number of U.S. hospitals providing obstetric care despite stable birth rates. It finds that the rate of neuraxial labor analgesia is now 84%, a significant increase that may help reduce maternal mortality. The study also highlights differences in practice between academic and nonacademic hospitals.

Cardiovascular Risk in Hypertensive Diso.title: Development and Validation of a Predictive Model for Maternal Cardiovascular Morbidity Events in Patients With Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy.
Cardiovascular Risk in Hypertensive Diso.author: N/A
Cardiovascular Risk in Hypertensive Diso.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a machine learning model to predict acute cardiovascular (CV) complications in patients with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP). Using a large healthcare database, the model predicted CV events during the delivery hospitalization with high accuracy (AUROC 0.878). The model identified chronic renal disease, cardiac disease, and preeclampsia with severe features as major risk factors, providing a tool to identify high-risk individuals.

POCUS in Preeclampsia.title: Prevalence of Point-of-Care Ultrasound Abnormalities and Raised Serum NT-proBNP in Early-Onset Preeclampsia.
POCUS in Preeclampsia.author: N/A
POCUS in Preeclampsia.abstract_summary: This study used point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) to assess cardiopulmonary status in 64 women with early-onset preeclampsia (EOPE). It found a high prevalence of pulmonary interstitial syndrome (PIS), systolic and diastolic dysfunction, and elevated LVEDP, though PIS was not associated with LVEDP. Women with EOPE had a higher prevalence of systolic dysfunction compared to historical controls with late-onset preeclampsia, highlighting distinct pathophysiological features.

Maternal Fever and Epidural Analgesia.title: Maternal fever, epidural analgesia, and genetics: implications for the neonate.
Maternal Fever and Epidural Analgesia.author: N/A
Maternal Fever and Epidural Analgesia.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses epidural-related maternal fever, a common occurrence affecting 15-25% of laboring women. It highlights the clinical challenge of distinguishing this from infectious fever to avoid unnecessary interventions for the neonate. The authors note there is no strong evidence of harm to the newborn and emphasize that women should be supported in their choice for pain relief.

Postdural Puncture Headache Treatment.title: No effect of tetracosactide for treatment of postdural puncture headaches in parturient women: a double-blind randomised controlled clinical trial.
Postdural Puncture Headache Treatment.author: N/A
Postdural Puncture Headache Treatment.abstract_summary: This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial investigated the efficacy of tetracosactide (a synthetic ACTH analogue) for treating postdural puncture headache (PDPH) in postpartum patients. The study was terminated early for futility, as there was no significant difference in the primary outcome of requiring an epidural blood patch between the treatment and placebo groups. The authors conclude that ACTH analogues should not be used for this indication.

Pediatric Regional Anesthesia Guidelines.title: Pediatric Regional Anesthesia: A Practical Guideline for Daily Clinical Practice.
Pediatric Regional Anesthesia Guidelines.author: N/A
Pediatric Regional Anesthesia Guidelines.abstract_summary: This review summarizes state-of-the-art information on pediatric regional anesthesia, highlighting its benefits for perioperative pain control and avoiding mechanical ventilation. It emphasizes the need for specialized knowledge of anatomy and techniques for successful implementation. The article serves as a practical guide for clinicians to incorporate a broad spectrum of pediatric regional anesthesia techniques into daily practice.

Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in C.title: Association between preoperative anaemia, transfusion, and outcomes in children undergoing noncardiac surgery.
Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in C.author: N/A
Preoperative Anemia and Transfusion in C.abstract_summary: This study analyzed data from pediatric patients undergoing noncardiac surgery between 2012 and 2023, finding that the incidence of preoperative anemia (25.7%) and transfusion (10.4%) remained stable. Preoperative anemia, perioperative transfusion, and especially the combination of both, were significantly associated with increased 30-day mortality and postoperative complications. The findings underscore the risks associated with anemia and transfusion in the pediatric surgical population.

Neuromuscular Blockade Reversal in Infan.title: Sugammadex for Reversal of Neuromuscular Blockade in Neonates and Infants Less than 2 Years Old: Results from a Phase IV Randomized Clinical Trial.
Neuromuscular Blockade Reversal in Infan.author: N/A
Neuromuscular Blockade Reversal in Infan.abstract_summary: This phase IV randomized trial evaluated the efficacy and safety of sugammadex in children under 2 years old. Sugammadex 2 mg/kg reversed moderate neuromuscular blockade significantly faster than neostigmine (median 1.4 min vs. 4.4 min). A 4 mg/kg dose rapidly reversed deep blockade, and both doses were well-tolerated, providing crucial safety and efficacy data for this vulnerable population.

Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Management.title: Impact of honey on post-tonsillectomy pain in children (BEE PAIN FREE Trial): a multicentre, double-blind, randomised controlled trial.
Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Management.author: N/A
Post-Tonsillectomy Pain Management.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial investigated whether honey could improve recovery after tonsillectomy in 400 children. When added to standard multimodal analgesia, neither Marri honey, Manuka honey, nor placebo significantly improved postoperative pain scores over a 14-day period. The study concludes that low-frequency honey administration does not provide additional clinical benefit for post-tonsillectomy pain.

Mortality Risk in Pediatric Cardiac Surg.title: Development and External Validation of a Novel In-hospital Mortality Model after Pediatric Congenital Heart Surgery: A Multicenter Retrospective Cohort Study.
Mortality Risk in Pediatric Cardiac Surg.author: N/A
Mortality Risk in Pediatric Cardiac Surg.abstract_summary: This study tested four traditional mortality risk models for pediatric congenital heart surgery in a Chinese population and found them to be only moderately effective. The researchers then developed and validated a new model incorporating six variables, including the STAT category and preoperative covariates. This novel model demonstrated superior performance and can serve as a useful tool for predicting in-hospital mortality risk in this specific patient population.

Quality of Recovery Assessment in Childr.title: Development of the Pediatric Scale for Quality of Recovery (PedSQoR).
Quality of Recovery Assessment in Childr.author: N/A
Quality of Recovery Assessment in Childr.abstract_summary: This study details the development of the Pediatric Scale for Quality of Recovery (PedSQoR), a new 20-item questionnaire to assess recovery in children after surgery. Created using a mixed-methods approach including literature review, expert panels, and patient/family interviews, the scale holistically measures physical and psychological recovery. Once fully validated, PedSQoR is expected to become a standardized, patient-centered outcome measure in pediatric perioperative care.

Airway Management Safety in Children.title: Adverse events associated with airway management in pediatric anesthesia: A prospective, multicenter, observational Japan Pediatric Difficult Airway in Anesthesia (J-PEDIA) study.
Airway Management Safety in Children.author: N/A
Airway Management Safety in Children.abstract_summary: This large prospective observational study in Japan (J-PEDIA) investigated adverse events during airway management in 16,695 children. Adverse events occurred in 2.0% of cases and desaturation in 2.3%, with neonates and infants at highest risk. Risk factors included younger age, certain surgical types, and anatomical difficult airway features, while supraglottic airway use and muscle relaxants were protective, providing valuable data to improve safety strategies.

Diaphragmatic Function Recovery in Child.title: Ultrasonographic assessment of sugammadex-enhanced early recovery of diaphragmatic function in children: A randomised double-blind controlled trial.
Diaphragmatic Function Recovery in Child.author: N/A
Diaphragmatic Function Recovery in Child.abstract_summary: This randomized trial compared sugammadex and neostigmine on diaphragmatic function in 73 children, assessed by ultrasound. The sugammadex group showed significantly faster recovery of diaphragmatic excursion and thickening immediately after extubation. However, this accelerated recovery did not translate into a significant reduction in the incidence of postoperative atelectasis.

Methylprednisolone Interaction with Suga.title: The effect of methylprednisolone on the reversal time of rocuronium by sugammadex in the paediatric patient group: A randomised controlled trial.
Methylprednisolone Interaction with Suga.author: N/A
Methylprednisolone Interaction with Suga.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial investigated whether methylprednisolone affects sugammadex reversal in pediatric patients undergoing tonsillectomy. The study found that administering methylprednisolone at induction significantly prolonged the reversal time of rocuronium by sugammadex by about 35 seconds. Although statistically significant, the authors conclude that the clinical importance of this interaction is minor.

Pediatric Premedication Strategies.title: Optimizing pediatric premedication for general anesthesia: A comprehensive Bayesian network meta-analysis.
Pediatric Premedication Strategies.author: N/A
Pediatric Premedication Strategies.abstract_summary: This Bayesian network meta-analysis of 69 trials evaluated the most effective premedication strategies for children undergoing general anesthesia. Combinations involving dexmedetomidine, midazolam, and ketamine were found to be most effective for improving mask acceptance, parental separation, and IV cannulation success. The study highlights that intranasal administration with shorter premedication times (15-30 min) showed greater efficacy, emphasizing that route, dose, and timing are critical factors.

Perioperative Management of Heart Failur.title: Outcomes in patients with chronic heart failure undergoing non-cardiac surgery: a secondary analysis of the METREPAIR international cohort study.
Perioperative Management of Heart Failur.author: N/A
Perioperative Management of Heart Failur.abstract_summary: This secondary analysis of the MET-REPAIR cohort study examined outcomes for patients with stable chronic heart failure undergoing major non-cardiac surgery. The study found that chronic heart failure was independently associated with a significantly increased risk of 30-day major adverse cardiovascular events, mortality, and severe in-hospital complications. A reduced ejection fraction (<40%) was specifically linked to a higher risk of adverse cardiovascular events.

Coagulation Monitoring in Cardiac Surger.title: Pre-operative reference ranges for ROTEM((R)) sigma in patients undergoing cardiac surgery: a secondary analysis of two prospective trial cohorts.
Coagulation Monitoring in Cardiac Surger.author: N/A
Coagulation Monitoring in Cardiac Surger.abstract_summary: This study established preoperative ROTEM sigma reference ranges for adult cardiac surgery patients and found significant differences compared to the manufacturer's ranges derived from healthy volunteers. Female patients exhibited a slightly more hypercoagulable profile than males, though the reference ranges were not significantly different. The findings suggest that cardiovascular-specific, but not necessarily sex- or age-specific, ROTEM reference ranges may be needed for this patient population.

Sedation in Pediatric Congenital Heart D.title: Remimazolam for successful sedation in children with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease: An up-and-down sequential allocation trial.
Sedation in Pediatric Congenital Heart D.author: N/A
Sedation in Pediatric Congenital Heart D.abstract_summary: This trial determined the effective dose of remimazolam for sedation in children aged 1-6 with left-to-right shunt congenital heart disease. Using an up-and-down sequential method, the study established the median effective dose (ED50) and 95th percentile effective dose (ED95) for different age subgroups (infants, toddlers, preschoolers). The findings provide crucial dosing guidance for preoperative sedation with remimazolam in this specific high-risk pediatric population.

Renal Protection in Cardiac Surgery.title: Perioperative Nitric Oxide Conditioning Reduces Acute Kidney Injury in Cardiac Surgery Patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (the DEFENDER Trial): A Randomized Controlled Trial.
Renal Protection in Cardiac Surgery.author: N/A
Renal Protection in Cardiac Surgery.abstract_summary: The DEFENDER trial, a randomized controlled study, evaluated the effect of perioperative nitric oxide (NO) in cardiac surgery patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). The NO group had a significantly lower incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury (23.5% vs. 39.7% in the control group) and better-preserved glomerular filtration rate at six months. The study concludes that perioperative NO administration is a safe and effective strategy to reduce AKI and slow CKD progression in this high-risk population.

Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.title: Pharmacokinetics of Methadone in Adult Patients Undergoing Cardiac Surgery With Cardiopulmonary Bypass.
Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.author: N/A
