Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.abstract_summary: This prospective study investigated the pharmacokinetics of intravenous methadone in 29 patients undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The results confirmed a significant drop in methadone concentrations during CPB, which was attributed to hemodilution and sequestration by the CPB circuit components. The study suggests that a supplemental methadone bolus of 0.05 mg/kg at the end of CPB can compensate for this effect.

Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.title: In Vitro Investigation of Insulin Dynamics During 4 Hours of Simulated Cardiopulmonary Bypass.
Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.author: N/A
Pharmacokinetics during Cardiopulmonary.abstract_summary: This in vitro study investigated the cause of insulin loss during simulated cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). Researchers found a substantial decrease in insulin levels only in circuits containing hemoglobin, with a more pronounced loss in the conventional roller pump circuit (cECC) which also showed more hemolysis. The study suggests that insulin degradation by hemolysis products is a more significant factor for insulin loss than adhesion to circuit surfaces.

Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.title: Perioperative cardiac arrest requiring admission to intensive care units in Japan: epidemiological differences between emergency and elective surgery.
Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.author: N/A
Perioperative Cardiac Arrest.abstract_summary: This nationwide retrospective study from Japan investigated the epidemiology of perioperative cardiac arrest in surgical ICU patients. The incidence was significantly higher in emergency surgeries (1.74%) compared to elective surgeries (0.17%). The study also found significant differences in the primary etiologies and clinical outcomes, with in-hospital mortality being much higher in the emergency surgery group (46.2% vs 15.8%).

Prehabilitation in Cardiac Surgery.title: Multimodal prehabilitation as a strategy to reduce postoperative complications in cardiac surgery: A randomised controlled trial.
Prehabilitation in Cardiac Surgery.author: N/A
Prehabilitation in Cardiac Surgery.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated a 4-6 week multimodal prehabilitation program for patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery. The program did not reduce the overall incidence of postoperative complications. However, a sub-analysis showed that patients who had a meaningful response to the exercise component experienced fewer and less severe complications, suggesting that patient response to prehabilitation may be key.

Management of Vasoplegia.title: Hydroxocobalamin for vasoplegia in cardiac surgery: a retrospective cohort analysis.
Management of Vasoplegia.author: N/A
Management of Vasoplegia.abstract_summary: This retrospective propensity-matched cohort study investigated the use of hydroxocobalamin for vasoplegia after cardiac surgery. In 229 matched pairs, hydroxocobalamin administration was associated with a significant reduction in vasopressor requirements over the first 24 hours. However, it did not impact the risk of a composite of in-hospital complications, highlighting the need for robust trials to determine its effect on clinical outcomes.

Cerebrovascular Compliance.title: Cerebral Blood Flow Under Pressure: Investigating Cerebrovascular Compliance with Phase Contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging During Induced Hypertension.
Cerebrovascular Compliance.author: N/A
Cerebrovascular Compliance.abstract_summary: This study used phase-contrast MRI to investigate how cerebrovascular compliance adapts to norepinephrine-induced hypertension in healthy adults. Researchers found that cerebral arteries significantly enhanced their compliance to buffer flow dynamics, a response not seen in systemic arteries. This suggests a unique protective mechanism in the cerebral circulation to handle increased blood pressure and maintain stable microcirculatory flow.

Cardiopulmonary Bypass Flow and Renal Ou.title: Effects of increased cardiopulmonary bypass pump flow on renal filtration, perfusion, oxygenation and tubular injury in cardiac surgical patients - a randomized controlled trial.
Cardiopulmonary Bypass Flow and Renal Ou.author: N/A
Cardiopulmonary Bypass Flow and Renal Ou.abstract_summary: This randomized trial in 36 cardiac surgery patients investigated whether a higher cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) flow rate improves renal outcomes. The high-flow group showed improved glomerular filtration rate and less pronounced release of a tubular injury marker compared to the standard-flow group, without changes in overall renal blood flow. These findings suggest that a higher CPB flow may be protective for the kidneys during cardiac surgery.

Postoperative Management after Thoracic.title: Impact of early high flow nasal oxygen on diaphragmatic function and pulmonary complications after thoracic surgery: A randomized clinical trial.
Postoperative Management after Thoracic.author: N/A
Postoperative Management after Thoracic.abstract_summary: This randomized trial assessed whether early high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) oxygen therapy could reduce diaphragmatic dysfunction and postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) after thoracic surgery. Overall, HFNC did not decrease the rate of these complications compared to conventional oxygen therapy. However, a post-hoc analysis revealed that for patients who did develop diaphragmatic dysfunction, HFNC significantly reduced the risk of PPCs.

Neuroprotection for Perinatal Hypoxic-Is.title: Xenon and Argon as Neuroprotective Treatments for Perinatal Hypoxic-Ischemic Brain Injury: A Preclinical Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.
Neuroprotection for Perinatal Hypoxic-Is.author: N/A
Neuroprotection for Perinatal Hypoxic-Is.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 21 preclinical studies evaluated the neuroprotective efficacy of xenon and argon in animal models of perinatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). Both gases showed significant neuroprotective effects, with argon demonstrating a greater summary effect than xenon. The findings provide strong preclinical evidence supporting further investigation of these noble gases as treatments for HIE.

Stochastic vs. Deterministic Emergence f.title: Emergence from general anaesthesia: stochastic or deterministic?
Stochastic vs. Deterministic Emergence f.author: N/A
Stochastic vs. Deterministic Emergence f.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study suggesting that emergence from general anesthesia is a stochastic (random) rather than a deterministic process, based on variability in emergence times in genetically identical mice. The authors question whether the righting reflex is an adequate marker for cognitive recovery. They propose that higher-level brain functions might follow more predictable emergence trajectories and call for future research using more comprehensive, cognition-sensitive markers.

Orexinergic Circuits in Arousal and Anal.title: Orexinergic projections to substantia innominata mediate arousal and analgesia.
Orexinergic Circuits in Arousal and Anal.author: N/A
Orexinergic Circuits in Arousal and Anal.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of orexinergic neurons projecting from the lateral hypothalamic area (LHA) to the substantia innominata (SI) in regulating arousal and pain. Using optogenetics in mice under isoflurane anesthesia, researchers found that activating this specific circuit promoted arousal and induced analgesia. The effects were mediated predominantly through the orexin receptor-2, identifying a key neural pathway involved in both anesthesia and pain modulation.

Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.title: Effects of an opioid-free care pathway vs. opioid-based standard care on postoperative pain and postoperative quality of recovery after laparoscopic bariatric surgery: A multicentre randomised controlled trial.
Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.author: N/A
Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial compared a total opioid-free care pathway (including intraoperative opioid-free anesthesia and postoperative TENS) with standard opioid-based care for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The opioid-free pathway resulted in comparable pain relief and quality of recovery outcomes. Importantly, it led to a significant reduction in opioid consumption both in the PACU and during the entire hospital stay.

Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.title: Opioid-free anaesthesia protocol based on thoracic paravertebral block enhances postoperative recovery after breast cancer surgery: A two-center, prospective, randomized, controlled trial.
Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.author: N/A
Opioid-Free Anesthesia Pathways.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated an opioid-free anesthesia (OFA) protocol using a thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) in patients undergoing breast cancer surgery. Compared to a conventional opioid-based anesthesia protocol, the OFA group had significantly higher quality of recovery scores at 24 and 48 hours postoperatively. The OFA protocol also resulted in lower pain scores and fewer instances of postoperative nausea and retching.

Opioid-Sparing and Multimodal Analgesia.title: Optimal multimodal analgesia combinations to reduce pain and opioid use following non-cardiac surgery: an instrumental variable analysis.
Opioid-Sparing and Multimodal Analgesia.author: N/A
Opioid-Sparing and Multimodal Analgesia.abstract_summary: This study used an instrumental variable analysis to identify optimal non-opioid medication combinations within multimodal analgesia (MMA) for non-cardiac surgery. Among 23,238 procedures, MMA was associated with reduced opioid use and pain scores. The greatest benefits were seen with combinations of NSAIDs plus either dexamethasone or regional anesthesia, suggesting these combinations are particularly effective and questioning the independent contribution of acetaminophen.

Ketamine for Postoperative Pain.title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Intraoperative Ketamine for Acute Postsurgical Pain after Breast Cancer Surgery: The Moderating Effect of Baseline Temporal Summation of Pain.
Ketamine for Postoperative Pain.author: N/A
Ketamine for Postoperative Pain.abstract_summary: This randomized trial investigated the effect of intraoperative ketamine on postoperative pain after breast surgery in 225 patients. Overall, ketamine showed no analgesic benefit over placebo. However, an exploratory analysis revealed that patients with higher baseline temporal summation of pain (a marker of central sensitization) did experience lower pain severity with ketamine, suggesting it may be effective in a specific patient subgroup.

Post-Surgical Opioid Management.title: One-year opioid consumption trajectories among individuals receiving multidisciplinary postsurgical care: a single-center observational study from the Toronto General Hospital Transitional Pain Service.
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.author: N/A
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.abstract_summary: This observational study tracked 466 high-risk patients at a Transitional Pain Service (TPS) for 12 months after surgery. The study identified three distinct opioid consumption trajectories and five pain intensity trajectories, all of which generally decreased over time. The findings highlight the heterogeneity in postsurgical recovery and underscore the importance of personalized, multidisciplinary care to optimize outcomes.

Post-Surgical Opioid Management.title: Postsurgical opioid prescribing among veterans using community care for orthopedic surgery at non-VA hospitals compared to a VA hospital with a transitional pain service: a retrospective cohort study.
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.author: N/A
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.abstract_summary: This retrospective study compared opioid prescribing for veterans undergoing orthopedic surgery at non-VHA hospitals versus a VHA hospital with a Transitional Pain Service (TPS). Veterans treated at the VHA-TPS facility were prescribed significantly fewer opioids at discharge and in the first 90 days post-surgery. They were also less likely to have persistent opioid use beyond 90 days, suggesting that integrated TPS programs can reduce opioid exposure.

Post-Surgical Opioid Management.title: Association of peripheral nerve blocks with increased postoperative pain and opioid use in orthopaedic surgery: a single-centre retrospective cohort study.
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.author: N/A
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.abstract_summary: This retrospective cohort study of over 22,000 orthopedic surgery patients found that while single-injection peripheral nerve blocks reduced immediate postoperative pain in the PACU, they were associated with higher pain scores and a 22.7% increase in opioid consumption during the subsequent hospital stay. Although associated with more opioid prescriptions at 30 days, nerve blocks were also linked to fewer chronic pain diagnoses at one year. The study suggests the need for standardized protocols to manage rebound pain and minimize long-term opioid exposure.

Post-Surgical Opioid Management.title: Postsurgical Medication Awareness, Recovery, and Tracking using a Phone-Based App (SMART-APP): a randomized clinical trial.
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.author: N/A
Post-Surgical Opioid Management.abstract_summary: This randomized trial tested whether a patient-facing educational smartphone app could reduce postoperative opioid use in surgical patients. Among 606 patients, the app did not significantly reduce self-reported opioid consumption in the 4 weeks after discharge compared to a control app. The study concluded that such digital tools might not be effective in surgical populations that already have low post-discharge opioid requirements.

ICD-11 Coding for Chronic Postsurgical P.title: Coding of post-surgical pain in ICD-11: between conceptual richness and practical constraints.
ICD-11 Coding for Chronic Postsurgical P.author: N/A
ICD-11 Coding for Chronic Postsurgical P.abstract_summary: This article discusses the new ICD-11 classification, which recognizes chronic postsurgical pain as a distinct clinical entity. It points out the gaps between the conceptual framework and practical clinical coding, highlighting inconsistencies. The authors call for better integration of diagnostic criteria and improved visibility of neuropathic and psychosocial dimensions of pain within the coding system.

Psychological Interventions for Postoper.title: Effectiveness of peri-operative psychological interventions for the reduction of postsurgical pain intensity, depression, anxiety and pain catastrophising: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Psychological Interventions for Postoper.author: N/A
Psychological Interventions for Postoper.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 27 RCTs evaluated perioperative psychological interventions on pain-related outcomes. The findings suggest that these interventions, particularly CBT delivered by a psychologist, can significantly reduce postoperative pain intensity and anxiety. However, the authors caution that the evidence quality is moderate and many trials had a high risk of bias.

Erector Spinae Plane Block for Lumbar Fu.title: Erector Spinae Plane Block in Multimodal Analgesia After Lumbar Spinal Fusion Surgery: A Blinded Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial.
Erector Spinae Plane Block for Lumbar Fu.author: N/A
Erector Spinae Plane Block for Lumbar Fu.abstract_summary: This randomized, placebo-controlled trial evaluated the effectiveness of a bilateral Erector Spinae Plane Block (ESPB) for postoperative pain after lumbar spinal fusion in 76 patients. The study found no significant difference in early postoperative pain intensity or 12-hour opioid consumption between the ropivacaine and saline groups. The authors conclude that ESPB has limited benefit within a multimodal analgesic regimen for this surgery and do not recommend its routine application.

Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.title: Oliceridine for postoperative pain and opioid-related complications: The intravenous oliceridine and opioid-related complications (VOLITION) prospective cohort study.
Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.author: N/A
Oliceridine for Postoperative Pain.abstract_summary: The VOLITION study prospectively evaluated the safety of oliceridine for postoperative pain in 204 patients after major noncardiac surgery. Clinically meaningful respiratory compromise occurred in 23% of patients, though none were life-threatening and no naloxone was required. The study highlights the need for a randomized trial to determine if oliceridine offers a better safety profile regarding opioid-related adverse events compared to conventional opioids.

Opioid Use Patterns in Trauma Patients.title: Population-based multistate modelling of peritraumatic opioid use among trauma patients from the Norwegian Trauma Registry.
Opioid Use Patterns in Trauma Patients.author: N/A
Opioid Use Patterns in Trauma Patients.abstract_summary: This study analyzed opioid use in over 24,000 trauma patients from the Norwegian Trauma Registry, finding that most with post-traumatic long-term opioid use were already users before the injury. Short-term opioid use peaked at 38.2% and returned to pre-injury levels within 6 months. The findings emphasize the need to address pre-existing opioid use to minimize post-traumatic dependency and highlight subacute and chronic pain as the primary indications for long-term use.

Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.title: Cortical integration and control of spontaneous neuropathic pain-like behaviour in mice.
Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study explored the role of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) in spontaneous neuropathic pain in mice. Using calcium imaging and optogenetics, researchers identified cortical hyperactivity in the ACC and found that inhibiting this region reduced spontaneous pain-like behavior. The findings reveal an essential role of the ACC in processing non-evoked pain, suggesting it as a potential target for treating spontaneous pain.

Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.title: Diminished transient receptor vanilloid 1 on skin nerve fibers in painful bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy.
Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Neuropathic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of TRPV1 receptors in painful bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy (BIPN) using skin biopsies. Researchers found that patients with painful BIPN had a greater reduction in TRPV1 immunoreactivity on skin nerve fibers compared to those with painless BIPN. This diminished TRPV1 presence was correlated with pain levels and reduced thermal sensitivity, offering new insights into the pathophysiology of pain in BIPN.

Predictors of Chronic Primary Pain.title: Predictive role of central nervous system-driven symptoms in the development of chronic primary pain.
Predictors of Chronic Primary Pain.author: N/A
Predictors of Chronic Primary Pain.abstract_summary: This commentary highlights a recent study using UK Biobank data that links central nervous system-driven symptoms like sleep disturbances and mood disorders to the subsequent development of chronic primary pain. The research suggests these symptoms precede chronic pain onset, indicating a potential window for early intervention. This enhances the understanding of nociplastic pain and emphasizes the need for preventive strategies for at-risk individuals.

Neurolysis for Chronic Hip Pain.title: Chemical ablation of pericapsular nerve group with 95% ethanol for pain relief and quality of life in patients with hip osteoarthritis: a prospective, double-blinded, randomised, controlled trial.
Neurolysis for Chronic Hip Pain.author: N/A
Neurolysis for Chronic Hip Pain.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated ultrasound-guided ethanol neurolysis of the pericapsular nerve group (PENG) for chronic hip osteoarthritis pain in 100 patients. The ethanol neurolysis group experienced significant and sustained pain reduction for up to 6 months, lower opioid consumption, and improved quality of life compared to the sham procedure. The study concludes that this is a safe and effective intervention for long-term pain relief.

Genetics of Chronic Pain.title: Sex-specific genetics underlie increased chronic pain risk in women: genome-wide association studies from the UK Biobank.
Genetics of Chronic Pain.author: N/A
Genetics of Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the genetic basis for the higher prevalence of chronic pain in women using UK Biobank data. Genome-wide association studies revealed that women have four times more sex-specific causal loci for pain than men, which are primarily enriched in specific brain regions. The research suggests that the genetics of brain phenotypes, particularly cortical thickness and striatal volume, are more often causally linked to chronic pain in women, highlighting a crucial genetic role in this sex disparity.

Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.title: Neurone-satellite glial cell interactions in dorsal root ganglia drive peripheral sensitisation in a mouse burn pain model.
Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.abstract_summary: This study investigated the mechanisms of peripheral sensitization in a mouse model of burn pain. Researchers found that burn injury upregulates CGRP in sensory neurons, which in turn activates satellite glial cells (SGCs) and enhances their gap junction coupling. This neuron-SGC interaction drives the release of chemokines like CXCL1, which potentiates neuronal excitability and pain, revealing a novel mechanism with potential therapeutic implications.

Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.title: A combined activity of peripheral nociceptive and nonnociceptive neurons is necessary to trigger spinal microglial reactivity and sustained pain.
Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Pain Sensitization.abstract_summary: This study investigated what type of nerve activity triggers spinal microglial reactivity, a key step in chronic pain development. Using optogenetics in mice, researchers found that selective activation of either nociceptive or non-nociceptive fibers alone was insufficient. Only the simultaneous activation of both fiber types induced sustained pain hypersensitivity and a spinal microglia response, suggesting that a combination of sensory inputs is necessary to initiate this central pain mechanism.

Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.title: Intrathecal Drug Delivery System in Prepontine Cistern for Patients with Intractable Craniofacial Cancer Pain: A Multicenter Retrospective Study.
Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.author: N/A
Intrathecal Drug Delivery for Cancer Pai.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study evaluated the safety and efficacy of placing an intrathecal morphine pump catheter in the prepontine cistern for 33 patients with intractable craniofacial cancer pain. The procedure resulted in a significant and progressive decrease in pain scores and breakthrough pain episodes over 30 days. This approach allowed for effective pain relief with an extremely low total morphine dose and few adverse events, suggesting it is a viable option for this challenging condition.

Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.title: Chemical hip denervation using phenol via Pericapsular Nerve Group (PENG) block in palliative non-operative management for frail older hip fracture patients: A multicenter retrospective cohort study.
Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.author: N/A
Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study evaluated chemical hip denervation with phenol via a PENG block in 185 frail, older patients with hip fractures managed non-operatively. The procedure provided acceptable pain control at rest and during care, with low opioid requirements, although mobility remained limited. The study suggests this technique is a viable analgesic option in a palliative, person-centered care approach for this vulnerable population.

Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.title: Navigating current controversies in radiofrequency ablation of the genicular nerves for chronic knee pain in osteoarthritis: a daring discourse.
Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.author: N/A
Interventions for Chronic Hip and Knee P.abstract_summary: This daring discourse article explores the ongoing debates and controversies surrounding radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of the genicular nerves for chronic knee osteoarthritis pain. It critically analyzes key issues, including the role of prognostic blocks, optimal nerve targets, guidance techniques (ultrasound vs. fluoroscopy), and the use of RFA after total knee arthroplasty. The aim is to guide clinicians in making informed decisions and to encourage further research to resolve these uncertainties.

Translational Pain Research.title: Translational control by general control nonderepressible 2 kinase regulates methylglyoxal-induced pain in mice.
Translational Pain Research.author: N/A
Translational Pain Research.abstract_summary: This study investigates the link between the metabolic byproduct methylglyoxal (MGO), associated with painful diabetic neuropathy, and the integrated stress response (ISR) in mice. Researchers found that MGO activates the ISR kinase GCN2 by disrupting ribosomes. Importantly, the neuronal sensitization and mechanical allodynia caused by MGO were dependent on GCN2, identifying it as a potential new analgesic target for diabetic neuropathy.

Translational Pain Research.title: Proteomic analysis of isolated nerve terminals from NaV1.9 knockout mice reveals pathways relevant for pain perception.
Translational Pain Research.author: N/A
Translational Pain Research.abstract_summary: This study investigated peripheral pain mechanisms by isolating and analyzing nerve terminals from the footpads of mice lacking the NaV1.9 sodium channel, which have impaired pain sensation. Proteomic analysis revealed dysregulation of key signaling pathways (MAPK and ERK1/2) and alterations in protein translation and mitochondrial components in the NaV1.9-deficient terminals. This approach uncovers peripheral signaling mechanisms in nociception and shows promise for translational research using human biomaterials.

Translational Pain Research.title: Enhancing clinical translation of analgesics for neuropathic pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis on the role of non-evoked pain assessment in preclinical trials.
Translational Pain Research.author: N/A
Translational Pain Research.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated the efficacy of standard analgesics on non-evoked pain (NEP) in preclinical neuropathic pain models to improve translational success. The study found that the efficacy patterns of drugs in relieving NEP in animal models closely matched their known clinical effectiveness in humans. These findings strongly support the incorporation of spontaneous pain assessments into preclinical studies to better predict the clinical potential of new analgesics.

Migraine Pathophysiology.title: Cortical astrocyte activation triggers meningeal nociception and migraine-like pain.
Migraine Pathophysiology.author: N/A
Migraine Pathophysiology.abstract_summary: This study investigated whether activating cortical astrocytes is sufficient to cause migraine-like pain in a rat model. Using chemogenetics to activate visual cortex astrocytes, researchers found it induced prolonged activity and sensitization of meningeal nociceptors, leading to migraine-like pain behaviors. These effects were suppressed by blocking CGRP signaling, suggesting that cortical astrocyte activation can trigger meningeal nociception and the subsequent migraine pain.

Assessment of Pain-Related Avoidance.title: Measurement instruments of pain-related avoidance in chronic pain: a systematic review of psychometric properties.
Assessment of Pain-Related Avoidance.author: N/A
Assessment of Pain-Related Avoidance.abstract_summary: This systematic review evaluated the psychometric properties of 22 different instruments used to measure pain-related avoidance in adults with chronic pain. Analyzing 140 articles, the review found that while many instruments exist, only two versions of the Chronic Pain Coping Inventory currently meet the criteria to be recommended for use. The study highlights a lack of high-quality evidence on measurement error and criterion validity for most tools, including commonly used ones like the Fear-Avoidance Beliefs Questionnaire.

Neuroplasticity in Musculoskeletal Pain.title: Prior use-dependent plasticity triggers different individual corticomotor responses during persistent musculoskeletal pain.
Neuroplasticity in Musculoskeletal Pain.author: N/A
Neuroplasticity in Musculoskeletal Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated how prior motor experience affects the brain's response to prolonged musculoskeletal pain by comparing musicians to non-musicians. After inducing prolonged pain with nerve growth factor, non-musicians showed a reduction in the motor map volume in the brain, a change not seen in musicians. The findings suggest that preexisting use-dependent plasticity from motor training, like playing an instrument, may counteract pain-related motor system changes and contribute to individual variability in pain response.

Interventions for Lumbar Radicular Pain.title: Pulsed radiofrequency of lumbar dorsal root ganglion versus epidural neuroplasty for lumbar radicular pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
Interventions for Lumbar Radicular Pain.author: N/A
Interventions for Lumbar Radicular Pain.abstract_summary: This network meta-analysis of 14 RCTs indirectly compared pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) of the dorsal root ganglion and epidural neuroplasty for treating lumbar radicular pain. While epidural neuroplasty showed a slight advantage over PRF at 3 months, there were no significant long-term differences in pain or disability outcomes. The authors conclude that the treatments may offer comparable results, but the low certainty of evidence limits confident clinical recommendations and highlights the need for direct comparison trials.

Social and Political Factors in Pain.title: Borders that hurt: the link between anti-immigration attitudes in Europe and the epidemic of chronic pain in immigrant adolescents.
Social and Political Factors in Pain.author: N/A
Social and Political Factors in Pain.abstract_summary: This study analyzed data from over 5,000 immigrant adolescents across 20 European countries to investigate the link between societal attitudes and health. It found that stronger country-level anti-immigration attitudes were significantly associated with a higher prevalence of chronic pain among these adolescents. This association was even stronger for immigrants with low socioeconomic status, suggesting that sociopolitical exclusion is a significant public health burden.

Chronic Pain and Sleep Apnea.title: Chronic pain is associated with sleep apnea severity but attenuated by intermittent hypoxemia in people using opioids.
Chronic Pain and Sleep Apnea.author: N/A
Chronic Pain and Sleep Apnea.abstract_summary: This study of 143 patients on long-term opioids for chronic pain found that sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) is linked to worsened pain symptoms and lower pain tolerance. Interestingly, this relationship was attenuated in patients with higher levels of associated hypoxemia. The findings suggest a complex interaction where SDB severity impacts pain, but the degree of oxygen desaturation modifies this effect, highlighting the importance of considering hypoxic burden in pain management.

Genetics of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.title: Familial risk of carpal tunnel syndrome among first-degree relatives and interaction with obesity and hyperglycemia-a population-based study in Korea.
Genetics of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.author: N/A
Genetics of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.abstract_summary: This large population-based study in Korea investigated the familial risk of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). Individuals with an affected first-degree relative had a nearly two-fold increased risk of developing CTS. Furthermore, there was a significant interaction between family history and both obesity and hyperglycemia, suggesting that individuals with these combined risk factors should be considered a high-risk population for CTS.

Psychology of Endometriosis Pain.title: Experience of endometriosis pain: a qualitative study.
Psychology of Endometriosis Pain.author: N/A
Psychology of Endometriosis Pain.abstract_summary: This qualitative study explored the pain experience of 16 women with endometriosis through in-depth interviews. Key themes emerged related to the nature of the pain, its impact on life, healthcare experiences, and the burden of being female. The study found that women expressed few fears about physical damage and did not avoid activities to protect themselves, questioning the applicability of the traditional fear-avoidance model of pain to this population.

Neuroimaging of Pain Habituation and Sen.title: Stable individual differences in habituation and sensitization to prolonged painful stimulation are underpinned by activity in the hippocampus, amygdala, and sensorimotor cortices.
Neuroimaging of Pain Habituation and Sen.author: N/A
Neuroimaging of Pain Habituation and Sen.abstract_summary: This study used fMRI to investigate the neural mechanisms behind individual differences in pain habituation and sensitization. In 85 participants, habituation to prolonged pain was associated with increasing activity in the hippocampus and amygdala, while sensitization was linked to increasing activity in sensorimotor cortices. The findings suggest that these response patterns are stable traits underpinned by differential activity in brain regions involved in sensory processing and appraisal.

Virtual Reality for Pain Relief.title: Immersion in nature through virtual reality attenuates the development and spread of mechanical secondary hyperalgesia: a role for insulo-thalamic effective connectivity.
Virtual Reality for Pain Relief.author: N/A
Virtual Reality for Pain Relief.abstract_summary: This study used immersive virtual reality (VR) to investigate the mechanisms of nature-based pain relief. In healthy participants, immersive nature VR significantly reduced the development and spread of experimentally induced secondary hyperalgesia compared to a 2D nature video or no intervention. Neuroimaging analysis suggested that this analgesic effect is mediated by insulo-thalamic effective connectivity, likely through top-down endogenous pain modulation systems.

Neuropathic Pain and Nerve Injury Models.title: Autoreactive immunoglobulin G levels and Fc receptor gamma subunit upregulation drive mechanical allodynia after nerve constriction or crush injury.
Neuropathic Pain and Nerve Injury Models.author: N/A
Neuropathic Pain and Nerve Injury Models.abstract_summary: This study in mice investigated the role of B cells and immunoglobulin G (IgG) in pain following different types of peripheral nerve injury. B-cell depletion prevented pain after nerve crush and constriction injuries, but not after nerve transection injuries (SNI/SNL). The results suggest that while all injuries drive secretion of pronociceptive IgG, only crush and constriction injuries upregulate the necessary Fc gamma receptors in the DRG and spinal cord, making them susceptible to IgG-driven pain.

Bladder Pain and Dysfunction Models.title: A catheter-associated urinary tract infection mouse model to study bladder dysfunction and pain.
Bladder Pain and Dysfunction Models.author: N/A
Bladder Pain and Dysfunction Models.abstract_summary: This study developed a new mouse model for catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTIs) to better study bladder pain and dysfunction. The model, involving a suprapubic catheter infected with E. coli, successfully recapitulated clinical symptoms like sustained infection, biofilm formation, bladder hypersensitivity, and voiding dysfunction. This novel research tool may be instrumental for developing new therapies for bladder-related pain and infections.

Psychological Interventions for Chronic.title: Understanding the untreated course of adults with chronic pain seeking psychological intervention: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Psychological Interventions for Chronic.author: N/A
Psychological Interventions for Chronic.abstract_summary: This meta-analysis of 52 studies examined symptom changes in chronic pain patients on waitlists for psychological treatment. Over an average period of 13.5 weeks, untreated participants showed very small but statistically significant improvements in pain intensity and disability, with no significant change in depression or anxiety. The findings suggest that, contrary to some reports, symptoms in this population are relatively stable over short waiting periods, which can inform service planning and treatment benchmarking.

Chronic Itch Biomarkers.title: Upregulated natriuretic peptide B expression as a hallmark of chronic itch.
Chronic Itch Biomarkers.author: N/A
Chronic Itch Biomarkers.abstract_summary: This study analyzed transcriptomic data from multiple animal models of chronic itch and pain to identify common molecular features. The analysis revealed that upregulation of natriuretic peptide B (Nppb) expression in sensory neurons is a consistent and selective feature of chronic itch models, but not pain models. The authors propose that Nppb, a known itch neurotransmitter, could serve as a conserved biomarker for chronic itch and may be a key contributor to the condition.

Interventions for Fibromyalgia.title: Analgesic benefits of pharmacological and nonpharmacological sleep interventions for adults with fibromyalgia: a systematic review and meta-analyses.
Interventions for Fibromyalgia.author: N/A
Interventions for Fibromyalgia.abstract_summary: This systematic review evaluated whether sleep-focused interventions can reduce pain in adults with fibromyalgia. Meta-analyses of 19 trials showed that sodium oxybate and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia both significantly improved pain outcomes compared to placebo and usual care, respectively. The findings provide preliminary support for the analgesic benefits of targeting sleep in fibromyalgia patients, though long-term effects require further investigation.

Nociceptor Signaling.title: STIM1 functionally couples to transient receptor potential ankyrin 1 contributing to nociception.
Nociceptor Signaling.author: N/A
Nociceptor Signaling.abstract_summary: This study reveals a novel link between the calcium sensor STIM1 and the nociceptive channel TRPA1 in sensory neurons. Researchers found that activation of TRPA1 triggers ER calcium release and STIM1-mediated calcium entry, which is critical for sensing cold, chemical, and noxious mechanical stimuli in mice. This discovery identifies STIM1 as a key transducer in nociception and provides new insights into TRPA1-mediated pain signaling.

Hormonal Effects on Pain.title: Androgen receptors expressed in the primary sensory neurons regulate mechanical pain sensitivity.
Hormonal Effects on Pain.author: N/A
Hormonal Effects on Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of androgen receptors (AR) in pain sensitivity using mouse models. Higher testosterone levels in males correlated with higher mechanical pain thresholds, an effect lost in gonadectomized or AR-knockout mice. The study demonstrates that ARs in primary sensory neurons, particularly CGRP+ neurons, are critical targets for androgens in regulating mechanical pain, suggesting a potential therapeutic approach for pain management.

Hormonal Effects on Pain.title: Androgen levels and experimental pain sensitivity in healthy young adolescent girls.
Hormonal Effects on Pain.author: N/A
Hormonal Effects on Pain.abstract_summary: This study examined the relationship between androgen levels and experimental pain sensitivity in 45 healthy adolescent girls. Unlike findings in adults, the study found no significant associations between levels of testosterone and other androgens with most measures of pain sensitivity. The results suggest that androgens have a minimal effect on pain perception in healthy girls during adolescence.

Neurophysiology of Pain Prediction.title: Neurophysiological encoding of aversive prediction errors.
Neurophysiology of Pain Prediction.author: N/A
Neurophysiology of Pain Prediction.abstract_summary: This study used magnetoencephalography (MEG) to investigate the brain signals underlying aversive prediction errors (PEs)—the difference between expected and actual pain. Researchers found that aversive PE signals are generated in the alpha band (8-12 Hz) in the midbrain, orbitofrontal cortex, and prefrontal cortex about 150ms after an outcome. These findings reveal the rapid neurophysiological mechanisms the brain uses to learn from unexpected painful or non-painful events.

Offset Analgesia Mechanisms.title: Peripheral contributions to offset analgesia: effects of stimulus duration, intensity, and location.
Offset Analgesia Mechanisms.author: N/A
Offset Analgesia Mechanisms.abstract_summary: This study investigated the peripheral nerve fiber contributions to offset analgesia (OA), a phenomenon of profound pain relief after a slight decrease in a noxious stimulus. By applying various heat stimuli to the hand, researchers found that OA was most prominent after long-duration stimuli and was inconsistently present after short or intense pulse stimuli. The results suggest that the slower-responding CMH nociceptors, rather than faster A-delta fibers, are likely critical for generating OA.

Cellular Mechanisms of Chronic Pain in H.title: Decreased KCC2 expression in the human spinal dorsal horn associated with chronic pain and long-term opioid use.
Cellular Mechanisms of Chronic Pain in H.author: N/A
Cellular Mechanisms of Chronic Pain in H.abstract_summary: This study provides the first human evidence for a key mechanism of chronic pain previously seen in rodent models. By examining tissue from organ donors, researchers found that the KCC2 chloride transporter was significantly downregulated in the spinal dorsal horns of individuals with a history of chronic pain or long-term opioid use. This finding supports the hypothesis that decreased inhibitory signaling in the spinal cord promotes chronic pain in humans and identifies KCC2 as a promising therapeutic target.

Nociplastic Pain Mechanisms.title: 12/15-lipoxygenases mediate toll-like receptor 4-dependent nociplastic pain hypersensitivity in female mice.
Nociplastic Pain Mechanisms.author: N/A
Nociplastic Pain Mechanisms.abstract_summary: This study investigated the mechanisms of nociplastic pain, which is more common in women, using a mouse model of central Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) activation. The researchers found that intrathecal lipopolysaccharide (LPS) induced a hyperalgesic phenotype in female mice mediated by 12/15-lipoxygenase (12/15-LOX) enzymes. Systemic inhibition of these enzymes reversed the pain behaviors, suggesting that 12/15-LOX are key druggable targets for nociplastic pain.

Pain Assessment in Preclinical Trials.title: Evaluating the efficacy of neurokinin-1 (substance P) receptor antagonist CP-99994 on facial grimacing and allodynia in mice postsurgery: a comparative study with known analgesics.
Pain Assessment in Preclinical Trials.author: N/A
Pain Assessment in Preclinical Trials.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the analgesic efficacy of the NK1R antagonist CP-99994 using facial grimacing, a measure of spontaneous pain, in mice after surgery. While known analgesics (carprofen, buprenorphine) reduced grimacing, CP-99994 showed limited effect on this measure, despite reducing evoked mechanical allodynia. The findings highlight a dissociation between spontaneous and evoked pain measures and suggest that assessing facial grimacing may better predict the clinical analgesic potential of drug candidates.

Genetic and Molecular Mechanisms of Pain.title: The impact of chronic pain on brain gene expression.
Genetic and Molecular Mechanisms of Pain.author: N/A
Genetic and Molecular Mechanisms of Pain.abstract_summary: This study analyzed brain gene expression in postmortem donors to understand the molecular basis of chronic pain. Researchers identified over 2,000 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) at the cellular level, with a significant enrichment in microglia of the basolateral amygdala. The findings highlight the heterogeneity of chronic pain's impact across brain regions and cell types and pinpoint amygdalar microglia as a key area for future research.

Autoimmunity in Chronic Back Pain.title: Spinal disk injury induces germinal center formation, pronociceptive antibody production, and chronic nociceptive sensitization in a male mouse back pain model.
Autoimmunity in Chronic Back Pain.author: N/A
Autoimmunity in Chronic Back Pain.abstract_summary: This study used a mouse model to investigate the role of the adaptive immune system in chronic back pain following spinal disk injury. The injury led to the formation of B-cell germinal centers in lymph nodes and the production of pronociceptive IgM and IgG antibodies, which contributed to chronic pain sensitization. These findings support the hypothesis that autoimmunity plays a key role in the transition from acute tissue injury to a chronic musculoskeletal pain state.

Intergenerational Transmission of Chroni.title: Identifying risk and protective factors in the transmission of chronic pain from mothers to children: a longitudinal cohort study.
Intergenerational Transmission of Chroni.author: N/A
Intergenerational Transmission of Chroni.abstract_summary: This longitudinal study of 1128 mother-child pairs identified psychosocial factors influencing the transmission of chronic pain. Children of mothers with chronic pain were more likely to develop chronic pain themselves, especially if the mother also had high anxiety or used ineffective parenting practices. Child-specific factors like optimism and strong social connections were found to be protective, lowering the risk of chronic pain regardless of maternal pain status.

Physiology of Pain Salience.title: Subjective salience ratings are a reliable proxy for physiological measures of arousal.
Physiology of Pain Salience.author: N/A
Physiology of Pain Salience.abstract_summary: This study investigated whether subjective salience ratings correlate with physiological arousal, measured by skin conductance response (SCR), for both painful and non-painful stimuli. In 41 healthy adults, there were no differences in SCR between heat pain and electric stimuli that were subjectively matched for salience. The findings validate the use of subjective salience ratings as a reliable proxy for physiological arousal, which is crucial for designing experiments that aim to isolate pain-specific brain processes.

Chronic Pain Flare-ups.title: Convergent validity of a person-dependent definition of a low back pain flare.
Chronic Pain Flare-ups.author: N/A
Chronic Pain Flare-ups.abstract_summary: This study validated a person-dependent definition of a low back pain (LBP) "flare" in a prospective study of 465 Veterans. Self-reported flare status was significantly associated with a 2.8-point higher pain intensity on a 0-10 scale, as well as greater pain interference and analgesic use. These findings support the convergent validity of this simple, patient-centered flare definition, which can be a valuable tool in LBP research and clinical practice.

Pediatric Pain Screening.title: Reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN: a screening tool for pediatric neuropathic pain and complex regional pain syndrome.
Pediatric Pain Screening.author: N/A
Pediatric Pain Screening.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reliability and validity of the Pediatric PainSCAN, the first screening tool for neuropathic pain (NP) and complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) in children. Tested in 221 pediatric chronic pain patients, the tool demonstrated sufficient test-retest reliability and criterion validity for identifying NP and CRPS. The Pediatric PainSCAN shows promise as a useful screening instrument in pediatric chronic pain clinics.

Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.title: Frailty and perioperative outcomes: SNAP-3 as a call to action.
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.author: N/A
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.abstract_summary: This article discusses the findings from the 3rd Sprint National Anesthesia Project (SNAP-3), which confirms that frailty is a key risk factor for adverse outcomes in older surgical patients. The author calls for action, urging anesthetists to identify patients with a Clinical Frailty Scale score of 4 or higher as being at elevated risk. It also advocates for a shift in research focus from risk factor identification to developing and evaluating interventions to improve outcomes for this growing patient population.

Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.title: Frailty in the perioperative setting: lessons from SNAP-3.
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.author: N/A
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.abstract_summary: This article summarizes the key lessons from the SNAP-3 study, the largest UK prospective study on frailty in older surgical patients. The study identified frailty in one-fifth of patients and found it was strongly associated with increased length of stay, delirium, complications, and mortality. The findings highlight the critical need for routine frailty screening and the development of frailty-focused perioperative services, especially in high-burden specialties and deprived areas.

Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.title: Postoperative outcomes in older patients living with frailty and multimorbidity in the UK: SNAP-3, a snapshot observational study.
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.author: N/A
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.abstract_summary: The SNAP-3 observational study of 7,129 older UK surgical patients investigated the impact of frailty and multimorbidity on postoperative outcomes. Increasing frailty was strongly associated with longer hospital stays, higher rates of delirium, morbidity, and mortality, with a clear rise in risk starting from a Clinical Frailty Scale score of 4. In contrast, multimorbidity alone had less impact, primarily affecting postoperative morbidity but not other major outcomes.

Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.title: Frailty and intraoperative hypotension: is the risk significant and modifiable?
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.author: N/A
Frailty as a Perioperative Risk Factor.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study demonstrating that frail patients are more likely to experience frequent intraoperative hypotension, and that these two factors work together to increase postoperative risk. The authors highlight that both frailty and hypotension are potentially modifiable risk factors through interventions like prehabilitation and continuous hemodynamic monitoring. They call for future studies to define which interventions provide the most benefit based on a patient's frailty status.

Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder (P.title: Patterns of prevention effectiveness in postoperative neurocognitive disorder and delayed neurocognitive recovery research: a systematic review with meta-regression of randomised trials.
Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder (P.author: N/A
Postoperative Neurocognitive Disorder (P.abstract_summary: This meta-regression of 187 randomized trials investigated factors associated with the effectiveness of interventions to prevent postoperative neurocognitive disorder (PND). The study found significant regional differences in trial outcomes, with studies from China reporting greater effectiveness. Other factors, such as higher baseline PND incidence and the use of dexmedetomidine, were associated with greater prevention effectiveness, highlighting the need to address these characteristics in future research.

Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.title: Long-term and pre-operative benzodiazepine use in older adults and risk for postoperative delirium: An additional analysis of the multicentre Biomarker Development for Postoperative Cognitive Impairment in the Elderly Study.
Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.author: N/A
Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.abstract_summary: This analysis of the BioCog cohort study investigated the association between benzodiazepine use and postoperative delirium (POD) in 928 elderly patients. Long-term benzodiazepine use was found to be significantly associated with an increased risk of developing POD, regardless of sex. In contrast, short-term use as a premedicant immediately before surgery was not associated with an increased POD risk, highlighting the importance of the timing and duration of benzodiazepine exposure.

Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.title: Preoperative low-dose dexmedetomidine reduces postoperative delirium in elderly patients with hip fracture under spinal anesthesia: A randomized, double blind, controlled clinical study.
Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.author: N/A
Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial investigated whether a continuous overnight infusion of low-dose dexmedetomidine could reduce postoperative delirium (POD) in elderly patients undergoing hip fracture surgery. The study found that patients receiving dexmedetomidine had a significantly lower incidence of POD (10.3%) compared to the placebo group (22.2%). The intervention also improved preoperative sleep quality and lowered postoperative inflammatory markers.

Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.title: Association Between Neuromuscular Blockade and Its Reversal With Postoperative Delirium in Older Patients: A Hospital Registry Study.
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.author: N/A
Neuromuscular Blockade and Postoperative.abstract_summary: This large hospital registry study of over 53,000 older patients found that the use of neuromuscular blocking agents (ND-NMBAs) was dose-dependently associated with a higher risk of postoperative delirium. However, this increased risk was mitigated by the administration of a reversal agent (neostigmine or sugammadex). The findings suggest that appropriate reversal of neuromuscular blockade may help reduce the incidence of delirium after surgery.

Trends in Arthroplasty for the Elderly.title: Trends in Comorbidities and Complications Among Octogenarians and Nonagenarians Undergoing Primary Total Joint Arthroplasty in the United States.
Trends in Arthroplasty for the Elderly.author: N/A
Trends in Arthroplasty for the Elderly.abstract_summary: This large database study analyzed trends in total knee and hip arthroplasty for patients aged 80 and older from 2006 to 2022. It found that while these very elderly patients often had fewer comorbidities than the typical 65-70 year old cohort, their age remained a significant independent risk factor for major postoperative complications. The study highlights the unique risk profile of this growing surgical population.

Risk Stratification in the Elderly.title: Age, ASA physical status and surgical outcomes: insights from a nationwide cohort study.
Risk Stratification in the Elderly.author: N/A
Risk Stratification in the Elderly.abstract_summary: This nationwide cohort study from Sweden analyzed over 460,000 surgical procedures to examine the relationship between ASA physical status, age, and postoperative mortality. The study confirmed a strong, graded association between higher ASA physical status and increased 30-day and 365-day mortality across all age groups. These findings reinforce the value of the ASA classification system for risk stratification in an aging surgical population.

Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.title: Dose-dependent relationship between intra-operative ketamine administration and postoperative delirium: a retrospective cohort study.
Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.author: N/A
Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.abstract_summary: This retrospective study of over 100,000 patients investigated the link between intraoperative ketamine dose and postoperative delirium. It found a U-shaped dose-response relationship: low-dose ketamine (≤ 0.35 mg/kg) was associated with a lower risk of delirium, while higher doses had no effect compared to no ketamine. The findings suggest that a specific low-dose range of ketamine may be neuroprotective.

Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.title: Effects of ketamine on postoperative cognition: a scoping review.
Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.author: N/A
Ketamine and Postoperative Cognition.abstract_summary: This scoping review summarized 58 clinical studies on the cognitive effects of perioperative ketamine in adult surgical patients. The results were inconsistent, with 60% of studies reporting no cognitive benefit and 40% reporting a reduced incidence or duration of perioperative neurocognitive disorders. Due to significant heterogeneity in study design and underpowered trials, the review concludes that larger, well-designed studies are needed to determine if specific patient subgroups might benefit from ketamine.

Digital Health Interventions in Ambulato.title: Post discharge digital health technology interventions in ambulatory surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Digital Health Interventions in Ambulato.author: N/A
Digital Health Interventions in Ambulato.abstract_summary: This systematic review of six RCTs evaluated the use of digital health interventions (DHIs) for post-discharge follow-up in ambulatory surgery patients. While meta-analyses showed no significant effect on pain intensity or unplanned healthcare encounters, individual studies suggested DHIs may reduce some symptoms, lower costs, and improve functional status. The authors conclude that while promising, more research is needed due to the limited number of studies and low certainty of evidence.

Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.title: Factors associated with a reduction in the preventive effect of intravenous dexamethasone on rebound pain after axillary brachial plexus block.
Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.author: N/A
Rebound Pain after Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: This study investigated factors that reduce the effectiveness of intravenous dexamethasone in preventing rebound pain after axillary brachial plexus block for ambulatory surgery. In 104 patients, factors associated with an increased risk of rebound pain included preoperative nocturnal pain, severe anxiety, high pain catastrophizing, and low salivary cortisol levels. These findings could help develop personalized strategies to prevent rebound pain.

Intraoperative Protective Ventilation.title: Intra-operative ventilation strategies and their impact on clinical outcomes: a systematic review and network meta-analysis of randomised trials.
Intraoperative Protective Ventilation.author: N/A
Intraoperative Protective Ventilation.abstract_summary: This network meta-analysis of 51 randomized trials evaluated different intra-operative ventilation strategies in non-cardiothoracic surgery. It found that low tidal volume ventilation strategies, when combined with various levels of PEEP and recruitment maneuvers, likely reduce the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications compared to high tidal volume with zero PEEP. The study reinforces the importance of lung protective ventilation and highlights the need for implementation research.

ICU Outcomes in Liver Disease.title: Outcomes for patients with alcohol-related liver disease admitted to Scottish intensive care units 2010-2018.
ICU Outcomes in Liver Disease.author: N/A
ICU Outcomes in Liver Disease.abstract_summary: This analysis of national Scottish data found that patients with alcohol-related liver disease admitted to the ICU had significantly higher mortality (36.7%) compared to other emergency non-surgical patients (22.5%). Mortality increased with the level of organ support required, but nearly 20% of patients on multi-organ support survived to discharge. The study suggests a trial of organ support may be appropriate, especially for those admitted with a gastrointestinal bleed, who had lower ICU mortality.

Ketamine for ICU Sedation.title: Ketamine Analgo-sedation for Mechanically Ventilated Critically Ill Adults: A Rapid Practice Guideline from the Saudi Critical Care Society and the Scandinavian Society of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care Medicine.
Ketamine for ICU Sedation.author: N/A
Ketamine for ICU Sedation.abstract_summary: This rapid practice guideline provides recommendations on using ketamine for analgo-sedation in mechanically ventilated ICU adults. Based on a systematic review, the panel issued two conditional recommendations: against using ketamine as a monotherapy when other agents are available, and for considering ketamine as an adjunct to usual care sedatives. The guideline highlights the very low certainty of evidence and calls for large-scale trials.

Rapid Response System Outcomes.title: Impact of the Standardized ICU Admission Ratio on Outcomes in Rapid Response System Activations: A Retrospective Multicenter Study in Japan.
Rapid Response System Outcomes.author: N/A
Rapid Response System Outcomes.abstract_summary: This multicenter retrospective study in Japan examined the relationship between ICU admission rates after Rapid Response System (RRS) activation and patient outcomes. The study found that institutions with higher Standardized ICU Admission Ratios (SIAR) had a significantly lower incidence of poor neurological outcomes or death within 30 days. This suggests that greater ICU utilization following RRS activation may improve patient outcomes, though further study is needed.

Nutritional Support for Ventilator Weani.title: Potential Benefits of Medical Nutrition Therapy for Timely Ventilator Weaning in the Critically Ill.
Nutritional Support for Ventilator Weani.author: N/A
Nutritional Support for Ventilator Weani.abstract_summary: This review explores the role of nutritional support and metabolic assessment in weaning critically ill patients from mechanical ventilation. It highlights that a personalized approach, integrating tools like indirect calorimetry and diaphragm ultrasound, is crucial. The review suggests that moderate, individualized protein intake and vitamin D optimization may improve weaning success, while evidence for high-fat diets or other supplements is currently lacking.

Lung Recruitment during General Anesthes.title: Evaluation of the potential for lung recruitment with the Recruitment-to-Inflation ratio during general anesthesia.
Lung Recruitment during General Anesthes.author: N/A
Lung Recruitment during General Anesthes.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the recruitment-to-inflation ratio (R/I), a ventilator-derived measure, to assess lung recruitability during general anesthesia. The R/I was found to be linearly correlated with recruited lung volume measured by gas dilution and tomography. Patients with a higher R/I required higher PEEP levels to optimize lung mechanics, suggesting that R/I can help identify individuals who may benefit from higher PEEP to achieve less injurious ventilation.

Pharmacokinetics in Kidney Transplantati.title: Reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade by sugammadex in patients undergoing kidney transplantation: Pharmacokinetics, efficacy, and safety analyses.
Pharmacokinetics in Kidney Transplantati.author: N/A
Pharmacokinetics in Kidney Transplantati.abstract_summary: This study investigated the pharmacokinetics, efficacy, and safety of sugammadex in patients with end-stage renal disease undergoing kidney transplantation. The elimination half-life of sugammadex was significantly longer in renal failure patients (10 hours) compared to healthy controls (2 hours), and clearance was significantly lower. Despite the slower clearance, sugammadex 2 mg/kg was safe and effective for reversing rocuronium in this patient population.

History of Ultrasound-Guided Regional An.title: The History of Ultrasound-guided Regional Anesthesia.
History of Ultrasound-Guided Regional An.author: N/A
History of Ultrasound-Guided Regional An.abstract_summary: This article revisits a classic 1994 paper that first described an ultrasound-guided technique for regional anesthesia. It recounts the initial skepticism and subsequent paradigm shift that ultrasound guidance brought to the field. The authors reflect on the 30-year journey of research, education, and collaboration that has made these techniques a global standard of care.

Liposomal Bupivacaine in Brachial Plexus.title: Addition of liposomal bupivacaine in brachial plexus blocks: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
Liposomal Bupivacaine in Brachial Plexus.author: N/A
Liposomal Bupivacaine in Brachial Plexus.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 21 RCTs assessed the efficacy of adding liposomal bupivacaine to brachial plexus blocks. While liposomal bupivacaine was associated with a statistically significant reduction in resting pain scores at 24, 48, and 72 hours, the evidence was rated as low-GRADE. The authors conclude that while there may be a benefit, its clinical significance is limited, and the effect is not consistently predictable.

Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST.title: The impact of local anesthetic systemic toxicity advisories on reporting to the National Poison Data System (NPDS).
Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST.author: N/A
Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST.abstract_summary: This study analyzed poison control data to assess the impact of the 2010 local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) advisories. Following the advisories, overall reports of local anesthetic poisoning decreased, but reports of lidocaine-related poisoning and mortality increased. The increase in lidocaine-related deaths was primarily in emergency settings, highlighting a need for improved guidance on its use to prevent mortality.

Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.title: Pharmacokinetic modelling and simulation for prolonged infusion of levobupivacaine with or without epinephrine in transversus abdominis plane and erector spinae plane blocks: a randomised controlled trial and analysis of pooled data.
Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.author: N/A
Pharmacokinetics of Local Anesthetics in.abstract_summary: This study analyzed the pharmacokinetics of levobupivacaine in transversus abdominis plane (TAP) and erector spinae plane (ESP) blocks. Epinephrine was found to significantly reduce systemic drug absorption by lowering bioavailability and prolonging absorption half-life. Pharmacokinetic simulations suggest that extended dosing regimens of 300 mg per 24 hours for 48 hours are likely to be safe for both blocks.

Diaphragm-Sparing Brachial Plexus Blocks.title: Hemidiaphragmatic paralysis after ultrasound-guided brachial plexus blocks for shoulder surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
Diaphragm-Sparing Brachial Plexus Blocks.author: N/A
Diaphragm-Sparing Brachial Plexus Blocks.abstract_summary: This systematic review of 28 RCTs compared various diaphragm-sparing regional techniques to conventional interscalene block (ISB) for shoulder surgery. Techniques like low-volume ISB, extrafascial ISB, and supraclavicular block significantly reduced the incidence of hemidiaphragmatic paralysis compared to conventional ISB. The findings provide conclusive evidence that certain modified techniques are less detrimental to diaphragmatic function.

Extended Reality for Procedural Guidance.title: Extended reality navigation for pain procedures: a narrative review.
Extended Reality for Procedural Guidance.author: N/A
Extended Reality for Procedural Guidance.abstract_summary: This narrative review explores the use of extended reality (XR) technology—including virtual, augmented, and mixed reality—for guiding pain procedures. While early trials show potential for XR to improve procedural efficiency, more research is needed to confirm significant clinical benefits. The review suggests best practices for developing XR navigation systems and discusses their future role in regional anesthesia and pain medicine.

Infection Control in Regional Anesthesia.title: ASRA Pain Medicine consensus practice infection control guidelines for regional anesthesia and pain medicine.
Infection Control in Regional Anesthesia.author: N/A
Infection Control in Regional Anesthesia.abstract_summary: These consensus guidelines from ASRA Pain Medicine provide evidence-based recommendations for infection control in regional anesthesia and interventional pain management. Developed through a modified Delphi method, the guidelines cover risk mitigation, diagnosis, and treatment of infectious complications. The recommendations address patient risk factors, sterile technique, equipment use, and postoperative management to serve as a multidisciplinary guide for clinical practice.

Pro-Con Debate on Loss-of-Resistance Tec.title: Pro-Con Debate: Air or Saline for Loss-of-Resistance Technique of Interlaminar Epidural Access with Fluoroscopy-Guided Pain Medicine Procedures.
Pro-Con Debate on Loss-of-Resistance Tec.author: N/A
Pro-Con Debate on Loss-of-Resistance Tec.abstract_summary: This article presents a Pro-Con debate on using air versus saline for the loss-of-resistance (LOR) technique in epidural access. The Pro-air side argues it is safe with low risk of pneumocephalus when using minimal volumes and fluoroscopy, and that it helps identify dural puncture. The Con-air side advocates for saline, citing evidence of fewer adverse events like headache and pneumocephalus and better tactile feedback, highlighting the ongoing debate over the standard of care.

Anesthetic Emergence.title: Emergence from general anaesthesia: stochastic or deterministic?
Anesthetic Emergence.author: N/A
Anesthetic Emergence.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study suggesting that emergence from general anesthesia is a stochastic (random) rather than a deterministic process, based on variability in emergence times in genetically identical mice. The authors question whether the righting reflex is an adequate marker for cognitive recovery. They propose that higher-level brain functions might follow more predictable emergence trajectories and call for future research using more comprehensive, cognition-sensitive markers.

Environmental Impact of Nitrous Oxide.title: Views of people who have given birth on the environmental and occupational exposure risks of nitrous oxide for labour analgesia: an interview-based qualitative study.
Environmental Impact of Nitrous Oxide.author: N/A
Environmental Impact of Nitrous Oxide.abstract_summary: This qualitative study interviewed 12 participants to understand their views on nitrous oxide for labor analgesia, considering its environmental impact and occupational risks. Participants viewed nitrous oxide as a safe, default option and felt institutions, not individuals, were responsible for mitigating its harms. While interested in the environmental risks, this information would not necessarily change their choice, highlighting the need for institution-led mitigation strategies.

Neurobiology of Pain.title: Microglia-neuronal communication mediated by P2X4R-BDNF-TrkB promotes synaptic plasticity and anterior cingulate cortex hyperactivity in muscle pain chronicity.
Neurobiology of Pain.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Pain.abstract_summary: This study investigated the role of microglia-neuronal communication in chronic muscle pain in rats. Researchers found that P2X4R-BDNF-TrkB signaling in the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) enhances synaptic plasticity and neuronal hyperactivity. Inhibiting this pathway or suppressing ACC hyperactivity relieved chronic pain and anxiety-like behaviors, highlighting this communication axis as a key target for developing novel therapies for muscle pain disorders.

Neurobiology of Pain.title: A ligand-receptor interactome of the bone tumor microenvironment in multiple myeloma bone pain.
Neurobiology of Pain.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Pain.abstract_summary: This study used computational analysis of transcriptomic data to map potential pain-causing interactions between cells in the multiple myeloma bone microenvironment and sensory neurons. The research identified specific ligand-receptor pairs and tested several ligands, finding that thrombospondin 1 directly increased intracellular calcium in sensory neurons. The study provides a map of potential nociceptive signaling pathways that could be targeted for future analgesic drug development.

Neurobiology of Pain.title: Silent information regulator sirtuin 1-mediated neuronal excitation-inhibition imbalance in the central amygdala is involved in peripheral nerve injury-induced depression-related behavior in mice.
Neurobiology of Pain.author: N/A
Neurobiology of Pain.abstract_summary: This study explored the mechanism behind depression-like behavior following peripheral nerve injury in mice, focusing on the central amygdala (CeA). Researchers found that downregulation of the histone deacetylase SIRT1 in the CeA leads to an excitation-inhibition imbalance (increased glutamatergic and decreased GABAergic activity). Overexpressing SIRT1 restored this balance and alleviated the depression-related behaviors, identifying SIRT1 as a key regulator and potential therapeutic target.

Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.title: Lost in conversion: navigating the challenges of converting intrathecal opioids to oral equivalents-a case report and literature review.
Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.author: N/A
Intrathecal Opioid Conversion.abstract_summary: This case report and literature review addresses the challenge of converting patients from long-term intrathecal opioid therapy to systemic opioids. It highlights the wide variability in published conversion ratios (from 1:2.5 to 1:300) and describes a case where a 1:10 ratio was ultimately used. The authors advocate for a conservative, patient-specific approach, starting with low conversion ratios and titrating carefully to ensure safety and efficacy.

Patient Satisfaction Assessment.title: Development and internal validation of the patient satisfaction questionnaire: Perception of Quality in Anaesthesia (PQA)-10.
Patient Satisfaction Assessment.author: N/A
Patient Satisfaction Assessment.abstract_summary: This study developed and validated a new, short questionnaire to assess patient satisfaction with anesthesia care in Switzerland, called the Perception of Quality in Anaesthesia (PQA)-10. Key themes identified by patients included communication, side-effects, and the professionalism of the anesthesia team. The final 10-item questionnaire demonstrated good reliability and validity, offering a quick and effective tool for measuring this key quality indicator.

Goal-Directed Hemodynamic Therapy.title: Perioperative Quality Initiative consensus statement on goal-directed haemodynamic therapy.
Goal-Directed Hemodynamic Therapy.author: N/A
Goal-Directed Hemodynamic Therapy.abstract_summary: This consensus statement from the 11th Perioperative Quality Initiative (POQI) conference provides updated recommendations on goal-directed hemodynamic therapy (GDHT). The panel recommends considering GDHT in specific settings like cardiac surgery and hip fracture surgery, but notes the evidence is weak. They recommend against routine use in major elective abdominal surgery and caution against fixed low-dose inotrope infusions as part of GDHT protocols.

AI for Perioperative ECG Interpretation.title: Artificial intelligence for electrocardiographic diagnosis of perioperative myocardial ischaemia: a scoping review.
AI for Perioperative ECG Interpretation.author: N/A
AI for Perioperative ECG Interpretation.abstract_summary: This scoping review assessed the current state of artificial intelligence (AI) for interpreting perioperative ECGs to detect myocardial ischemia. While AI algorithms show high diagnostic accuracy on clean, pre-existing ECG databases, there is a lack of studies testing these technologies on the noisy, continuous data characteristic of the perioperative environment. The authors call for future research to develop and validate AI algorithms on real-world perioperative ECGs to improve their clinical applicability.

AI for Echocardiography Report Analysis.title: Generative AI models: the next anaesthetic agent?
AI for Echocardiography Report Analysis.author: N/A
AI for Echocardiography Report Analysis.abstract_summary: This commentary discusses a recent study that successfully used an ensemble of large language models (LLMs) to extract structured data from unstructured, free-text transesophageal echocardiography reports. The authors highlight the high accuracy and manageable error rates of this AI-driven approach. They suggest that this work not only solves a specific data-handling challenge but also points toward broader applications of AI in streamlining perioperative care.

Entropic EEG Features in Children.title: Age-Dependent Entropic Features During Propofol Anesthesia in Developing Brain.
Entropic EEG Features in Children.author: N/A
Entropic EEG Features in Children.abstract_summary: This study investigated entropy-based EEG measures (PeEn, SampEn) for monitoring propofol anesthesia depth in children aged 1-18. Frontal permutation entropy (PeEn) provided excellent accuracy in distinguishing unresponsiveness from recovery, outperforming BIS in toddlers. The study also found that frontal complexity decreased with age during propofol maintenance, reflecting developmental changes in the brain, particularly during adolescence.

Graduate Medical Education Assessment.title: How Well Do Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education Milestones Track Readiness for Anesthesiology Certifying Examinations in a National Resident Cohort?
Graduate Medical Education Assessment.author: N/A
Graduate Medical Education Assessment.abstract_summary: This study compared ACGME Milestones ratings with American Board of Anesthesiology (ABA) examination performance for a national cohort of anesthesiology residents. While the Medical Knowledge Milestone showed a modest correlation with the written ADVANCED Examination, there were only weak or no significant correlations between other Milestones and the oral (SOE) or clinical (OSCE) exams. The findings suggest that the Milestones system, as currently implemented, does not effectively predict performance on the certifying examinations.

Graduate Medical Education Assessment.title: Reliability and utility of anesthesiology entrustable professional activities assessed with a mobile web application.
Graduate Medical Education Assessment.author: N/A
Graduate Medical Education Assessment.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reliability and utility of assessing 14 anesthesiology Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) using a mobile web application. While the Web App was deemed useful for formative, low-stakes assessment, only two of the seven tested EPAs were effective at discriminating differences in resident performance.
