The study suggests that while individual EPA assessments can be part of a competency-based education framework, not all EPAs may be suitable for reliably measuring performance differences.

Causal Inference in Observational Studie.title: DAGs for dummies: how to extract causation from correlation.
Causal Inference in Observational Studie.author: N/A
Causal Inference in Observational Studie.abstract_summary: This article provides an introduction to directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) as a tool for improving causal inference in observational research. It explains how DAGs help researchers visually map assumptions about confounders, mediators, and colliders to guide appropriate statistical adjustments. By promoting a transparent and structured approach, DAGs can help distinguish likely causation from mere correlation, strengthening the rigor of observational studies.

Causal Inference in Observational Studie.title: Directed acyclic graphs to minimise bias and optimise causal inference in SNAP-3: an observational cohort study of frailty, multimorbidity, and delirium in older surgical patients.
Causal Inference in Observational Studie.author: N/A
Causal Inference in Observational Studie.abstract_summary: This paper describes the development and use of directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) to guide the statistical analysis of the SNAP-3 observational study on older surgical patients. By visually representing causal assumptions between variables like frailty, multimorbidity, and delirium, DAGs provide a transparent and objective framework for selecting appropriate statistical adjustments. This approach helps to minimize bias and optimize causal inference in complex clinical research.

Biomarkers for Postoperative Nausea and.title: Association between plasma growth differentiation factor-15 and postoperative nausea and vomiting incidence and severity: a secondary analysis of a randomised trial.
Biomarkers for Postoperative Nausea and.author: N/A
Biomarkers for Postoperative Nausea and.abstract_summary: This study investigated plasma growth differentiation factor-15 (GDF-15) as a biomarker for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in patients undergoing laparoscopic gastrointestinal surgery. Researchers found that lower preoperative GDF-15 concentrations were significantly associated with a higher risk of PONV. This suggests that GDF-15 could be a useful biomarker to identify at-risk patients and optimize prophylactic strategies.

Postoperative Recovery Trajectories.title: Quality of patient-centred recovery trajectories after different types of surgery: a prospective cohort study.
Postoperative Recovery Trajectories.author: N/A
Postoperative Recovery Trajectories.abstract_summary: This prospective cohort study tracked patient recovery trajectories using the QoR-15 score and days alive at home (DAH30) for up to 90 days after different types of surgery. The study found that the depth and speed of recovery varied significantly with the extent of surgery, with cardiac surgery patients showing the slowest recovery. The frequent text message-based follow-up was highly valued by patients, suggesting its utility for monitoring patient-centered outcomes.

Postoperative Hypotension.title: New-onset postoperative hypotension in patients recovering from noncardiac surgery: A prospective observational study.
Postoperative Hypotension.author: N/A
Postoperative Hypotension.abstract_summary: This observational study assessed postoperative arterial pressure in 248 patients on general wards after noncardiac surgery. It found that while 41% of patients had at least one mean arterial pressure reading below 65 mmHg, for nearly half of them (18% of the total cohort), this represented new-onset hypotension compared to their preoperative baseline. The study highlights that a simple threshold of 65 mmHg may not be clinically relevant for all patients and that individual baselines should be considered.

Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.title: To trial or not to trial before peripheral nerve stimulation for chronic pain: a retrospective multicenter comparative analysis of temporary-to-permanent and direct-to-permanent implantation approaches.
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.author: N/A
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This retrospective study compared outcomes for patients receiving permanent peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) with or without a prior temporary trial. The analysis of 130 patients found no evidence that a temporary-to-permanent (TTP) approach was associated with superior pain relief or opioid reduction at 6 months compared to a direct-to-permanent (DTP) approach. The findings question the necessity of routine temporary trials before permanent PNS implantation.

Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.title: Clinical study of a micro-implantable pulse generator for the treatment of peripheral neuropathic pain: 3-month and 6-month results from the COMFORT-randomised controlled trial.
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.author: N/A
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This randomized controlled trial evaluated a micro-implantable pulse generator (micro-IPG) for peripheral nerve stimulation (PNS) in treating chronic peripheral pain. At the 3-month primary endpoint, the PNS group achieved an 84% responder rate and 67% pain reduction, significantly better than the control group (3% responder rate, 6% pain reduction). These results demonstrate that PNS with this micro-IPG is a safe and efficacious treatment for chronic peripheral pain.

Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.title: Guidelines on neurostimulation for chronic pain: a compliance appraisal of reporting standards.
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.author: N/A
Neuromodulation for Chronic Pain.abstract_summary: This study evaluated the reporting quality of 24 clinical practice guidelines on neurostimulation for chronic pain using the RIGHT and AGREE checklists. The mean completion rate for checklist items was low (around 55%), with significant under-reporting in areas like population-specific considerations, cost implications, and management of competing interests. The findings highlight a need for improved comprehensiveness and transparency in future guideline development.

Gabapentin and Dementia Risk.title: Risk of dementia following gabapentin prescription in chronic low back pain patients.
Gabapentin and Dementia Risk.author: N/A
Gabapentin and Dementia Risk.abstract_summary: This retrospective cohort study using a large national database investigated the association between gabapentin and dementia in adults with chronic low back pain. After propensity-score matching, patients with six or more gabapentin prescriptions had a significantly increased incidence of dementia and mild cognitive impairment. The risk was particularly pronounced in non-elderly adults (18-64), suggesting a need for cognitive monitoring in patients prescribed gabapentin.

Spinal Cord Stimulation and Mobility.title: Objective, long-term mobility data in patients with chronic pain after lumbar spine surgery treated with spinal cord stimulation-a prospective, multicenter trial.
Spinal Cord Stimulation and Mobility.author: N/A
Spinal Cord Stimulation and Mobility.abstract_summary: This prospective trial objectively measured mobility using an accelerometer in patients with chronic pain after lumbar spine surgery who received spinal cord stimulation (SCS). Over 12 months, SCS treatment led to a gradual and significant increase in mobility, particularly in patients with predominant leg pain. This increase in mobility correlated with improvements in self-reported disability and pain, providing objective evidence of SCS's long-term benefits.

Hospitalized Headache Management.title: Practice advisory for intravenous management of headache disorders in hospitalized patients: a review of the evidence and consensus recommendations.
Hospitalized Headache Management.author: N/A
Hospitalized Headache Management.abstract_summary: This practice advisory provides evidence-based recommendations for the intravenous management of headache disorders in hospitalized patients, addressing a critical gap in current guidance. Through a systematic literature review and a modified Delphi process, a panel of experts generated 12 statements and 17 recommendations. The advisory aims to standardize inpatient headache care and highlights the need for more rigorous prospective studies in this area.

Bone Cement Implantation Syndrome.title: Bone cement implantation syndrome: a scoping review.
Bone Cement Implantation Syndrome.author: N/A
Bone Cement Implantation Syndrome.abstract_summary: This scoping review provides a comprehensive overview of bone cement implantation syndrome (BCIS), a serious complication of arthroplasty involving hypoxemia, hypotension, or cardiac arrest. The review summarizes incidence rates (15-70% depending on the joint), identifies risk factors such as advanced age and ASA status 3-4, and notes that the syndrome can occur even in uncemented arthroplasty. The paper emphasizes the need for a better understanding of this syndrome as the number of arthroplasties increases.

Association between Chronic Pain and Hyp.title: Are adults with chronic pain more likely to develop hypertension than adults without chronic pain? A systematic review and meta-analysis.
Association between Chronic Pain and Hyp.author: N/A
Association between Chronic Pain and Hyp.abstract_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of 23 studies investigated the association between chronic pain (CP) and hypertension (HTN). The pooled analysis of over 1.5 million participants revealed that people with CP had a 66% higher odds of having HTN compared to controls. The association was particularly strong for chronic widespread pain and chronic headache, confirming a significant link between these conditions.
